Most hikers and climbers approaching "Les Trois Tétons" depart from the Lupine Meadows trailhead. Conifers canopy the first part of the trail giving way to shrub-covered slopes with views of the valley. The trail splits three miles up from the trailhead. The north fork climbs to Surprise and Amphitheater lakes at the base of Disappointment Peak. The south fork wraps around into Garnet Canyon with a stunning view of the Middle Teton. Garnet Canyon trail is the primary access route for climbing the Grand Teton.

Amphitheater Lake
10.1 miles RT, 7 hours, 3000 ft total climbing, Strenuous.
Hike to glacial lakes surrounded by meadows. Disappointment Peak towers above.

Garnet Canyon
8.4 miles RT, 6 hours, 2650 ft total climbing, Strenuous.
Trail climbs into Garnet Canyon offering spectacular views of the Middle Teton.

Location

Access the Lupine Meadows Trailhead from the Teton Park Road one mile south of South Jenny Lake Junction. Turn west and follow a gravel road for about one and a half miles.

Things to Know

Visitor services include gravel parking lot, a vault toilet, bear food storage boxes and a trailhead sign. Remember to bring water with you.

Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray.

Backcountry camping requires a permit-pick one up at a backcountry permits office. Overnight parking is only allowed with a backcountry permit, no camping in parking lot.

Name Origin

Silver lupine blooms in the meadow during early summer.
audioDescription: This three-panel sign covered by a small roof is located just to the right of a wide, level dirt path which heads south through the conifer woods. If you place your back to the sign, the dirt parking area is ahead of you, outlined by widely-spaced white boulders. The parking area is bordered on the right by open meadows with scattered fir trees. A unisex vault toilet is on the left side of the parking area at the far end from the trailhead.The center panel on the sign shows a map of the area from your current location at the base of Teewinot Mountain south to Taggart Lake at the end of Avalanche Canyon. The map is oriented with north pointing in the five-o'clock direction. Dotted lines show the trails that can be accessed from this location. The panel reads, "Explore Your Park. There is perhaps no climbing area in the country that can match the Teton Range for alpine mountaineering with excellent rock, moderate snow and, above all, accessibility. Every year thousands of climbers begin their journey here to the Grand Teton summit. Whether you came to hike or climb, these trails provide some of the best views of the range's central peaks."DID YOU REMEMBER?- Sunscreen: The sun burns quickly at this elevation.- Clothing Layers: Weather can change suddenly.- Plenty of Food & Water: Avoid the dangers of dehydration and fatigue.- Bug Spray: Don't let mosquitoes ruin your trip.- Map & Watch: Avoid spending an unplanned night in the backcountry with careful planning and routefinding.- Bear Spray: Both grizzly and black bears thrive in Grand Teton National Park."RECOMMENDED ROUTES- Valley Trail - Hike through forest and meadow to meet with the Valley Trail, continue south to Bradley Lake. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 6.4 miles; DURATION: 4 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 1,350 feet; DIFFICULTY: moderate.- Surprise and Amphitheater Lakes - Hike along a moraine and up switchbacks through forest and meadows to two alpine lakes. Watch for bears, frequently seen along this trail. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 10 miles; DURATION: 6 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 3,150 feet; DIFFICULTY: strenuous.- Garnet Canyon - Trail climbs up switchbacks to Garnet Canyon for excellent valley views and access to the central peaks. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 8.2 miles; DURATION: 5 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 2,650 feet; DIFFICULTY: strenuous."Risk and Responsibility - Like other recreational pursuits, climbing carries inherent personal risk. It is the responsibility of the individual climber to minimize risk by exercising good judgment and making sure he/she has the proper mountaineering skills necessary to survive in an alpine environment."* Duration and degree of difficulty will vary individually. For more trip suggestions ask at a visitor center."Stock Users - Inquire at a visitor center, ranger station or entrance station for regulations and trails open to stock."Emergencies - The nearest telephone is located at the Jenny Lake Visitor Center, about 2 1/2 miles north of here."Did You Know? Paul Petzoldt began guiding aspiring climbers within days of his own first ascent of the Grand Teton in 1924. Early clients that year included William Owen - who in 1898 claimed the first documented ascent of the Grand. Petzoldt and his partner Glenn Exum established an American guiding tradition, teaching climbing techniques to clients rather than shepherding them to the top."The left hand panel has a photograph of a climber on the side of a rock face with a jagged peak visible in the background. Text reads, "Protect the Backcountry. "HIKING, CAMPING & STOCK USE- All overnight stays require a backcountry camping permit. Permits are available year-round at the visitor center in Moose, and during the summer at Jenny Lake Ranger Station and Colter Bay Visitor Center.- Pack out all trash. Keep the park litter-free for all to enjoy.- Stay on established trails. Shortcutting switchbacks damages plants and causes erosion.- Backcountry campfires are allowed ONLY at designated lakeshore sites and must be confined to metal grates or with a permit below the Jackson Lake high water line.- Backpackers must use park-approved bear-resistant canisters or food storage lockers when camping below 10,000 feet.- Saddle and pack animals must stay on authorized trails and may not graze in the park. Find out more at a visitor center."CLIMBING & MOUNTAINEERING- Registration is not required for technical climbing or mountaineering; however, a permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry.- Tell a friend or family member your plans and when you expect to return.- During summer visit the Jenny Lake Ranger Station for details on climbing routes and current conditions.- Follow low impact climbing ethics. Leave the rock in its natural condition. Avoid placing permanent protection. Motorized drills are prohibited.- RESOURCE PROTECTION & FIREARMS- Leave the park as you found it for others to enjoy. Picking wildflowers or collecting any object is prohibited.- Hikers must be prepared for wildli

title: Maud Noble Cabin
listingDescription: Maud Noble came to the valley as a dude rancher at the Bar BC Ranch summer of 1915. She moved to the valley permanently in 1916 and contracted a cabin on the east side of Cottonwood Creek. She purchased the Menor homestead in 1918 and had her cabin moved to the homestead. With her partner Frederick Sandell, she ferried increasing numbers of visitors across the Snake River and ran the Ferry Ranch Store.In 1923, a group of local residents and Horace Albright, Superintendent of

images.altText: Maud Noble cabin brown log with white chinking. Spruce trees grow overhead.
images.caption: Maud Noble Cabin

bodyText:
Maud Noble came to the valley as a dude rancher at the Bar BC Ranch summer of 1915. She moved to the valley permanently in 1916 and contracted a cabin on the east side of Cottonwood Creek. She purchased the Menor homestead in 1918 and had her cabin moved to the homestead. With her partner Frederick Sandell, she ferried increasing numbers of visitors across the Snake River and ran the Ferry Ranch Store.

In 1923, a group of local residents and Horace Albright, Superintendent of Yellowstone National Park, met at Noble's cabin to discuss their concerns over commercial development along the base of the Teton Range. The alarmed meeting participants discussed ways to save the valley from tawdry exploitation. They agreed that some sort of preserve would be necessary to protect the "Old West" character of the valley, though their concept of a preserve was different from a national park. The group decided to seek a wealthy individual who would be willing to buy private land to donate to the preserve -- that person was John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

In 1927, a steel truss bridge was built just south of the ferry, making it obsolete. Maud Noble sold the property to the Snake River Land Company in 1929.
audioDescription:
This log-and-white-chinked building is a rectangle with the front door in the long side. An extension is built out from the left back. A stone chimney sits outside the left hand wall. A small lean-to roof shelters the front door. Two wooden benches flank the door. Near the path to the left of the door a small sign reads, "Park Takes Root. On July 26, 1923, Maud Noble hosted a landmark meeting in this cabin. Yellowstone National Park Superintendent Horace Albright joined a small group of locals here. They launched a plan that planted the seed for the creation of Grand Teton National Park."

Hanging on the wall to the right of the front door is a bronze plaque which commemorates that meeting. A short, low ramp covers the shallow step into the cabin. Inside the door rustic wood period chairs and tables are grouped around the fireplace. Other rooms may be accessed to the rear and to the right.

title: Menors Ferry - East Side
listingDescription: West of Dornans, Holiday Menor homesteaded along the east bank of the Snake River in 1908. He moved here to join his brother Bill who homesteaded across the river and operated a ferry and general store. Under the shed next to the river is one of the pontoons from the ferry-the last remaining part of the original boat. Holiday operated a limekiln burning limestone at high temperatures to produce pure lime. Settlers used lime to chink cabins and to whitewash their buildings.

images.altText: Looking across the Snake River toward the cabins of Bill Menors homestead with the Teton Range beyond.
images.caption: Snake River and Bill Menors Homestead

bodyText:
West of Dornans, Holiday Menor homesteaded along the east bank of the Snake River in 1908. He moved here to join his brother Bill who homesteaded across the river and operated a ferry and general store. Under the shed next to the river is one of the pontoons from the ferry-the last remaining part of the original boat.

Holiday operated a limekiln burning limestone at high temperatures to produce pure lime. Settlers used lime to chink cabins and to whitewash their buildings. Bill's cabin is one of the few whitewashed buildings in the area.
audioDescription: From the parking lot at Dornans Service District a paved trail leads down to the east side of the river and the ferry crossing. There are three wayside signs along the trail. From the first sign at the edge of the parking lot, a brushy meadow stretches out in front of you to a thin line of trees at the waters edge. The right side of the sign shows a map of the area with the Teton Range to the west, the valley of Jackson Hole to the east and Menor's Ferry along the Snake River in the middle. An inset photograph shows a historic image of the ferry crossing the river carrying a wagon and team of horses.Text on the left reads, "Menor's Ferry Historic District. This area was settled by two brothers, Bill and Holiday Menor, originally from Ohio. Bill settled on the west side of the river in 1894 and established an important river crossing with his ferry. Holiday followed in 1905 and eventually homesteaded on the east side, just across the river from his brother."Jackson Hole was one of the last areas of the West to be settled, probably because its geographic isolation, harsh climate, and high elevation were not conducive to agriculture. The first settlers came in 1884, and by 1888 Jackson Hole had a population of 20 men, two women, and one child. During the 1890s Mormon settlers came from Idaho and Utah. Many of them crossed the Snake River at Menors' Ferry and settled just east of here in an area the called Grovont, now known as Mormon Row. The census of June 1, 1900 revealed that 638 people lived in the valley of Jackson Hole; the major occupation was farming."At the bottom left are small portraits of two men. Bill Menor is on the left and Holiday Menor on the right.About halfway down the gently sloped paved trail is another wayside just to the right of the walkway. It looks out over a scrubby meadow with a high bank on the right and the trees lining the river on the left. The background image on the panel shows a historic photograph of the same view. A dirt tack runs along the base of the bank towards three small log buildings with a larger, framed barn in the background. Text reads, "Holiday Menor's Homestead. Holiday Menor first came to Jackson Hole in 1905 after working as a gold prospector in Montana. He lived with his brother Bill until 1908, when he established a 160-acre homestead on this land. He grew wheat, barley, and alfalfa, which he sold to ranchers to feed to their cattle during the long harsh winters.He also built a limekiln that was used for several days each year to burn the limestone he quarried from Blacktail Butte. Lime was important to settlers; they mixed it with sand and water to make mortar for chinking log cabins and for laying bricks and stonework. Lime was also used as a whitewash (see Bill's cabin across the river) and to reduce odors in outhouses. About 250 bushels of lime, which sold for 50 cents a bushel, were produced each year."At the top right of the panel is a small historic photo of a man wearing a hat ad a black vest, leaning against a log wall. The caption reads, "Holiday sold his homestead to the Snake River Land Company in 1928 and joined Bill, who had already retired and was living in San Diego, California."At the bottom left of the panel is an illustration of a lime kiln. A tall shaft, surrounded by dirt, is full of white stones. At the bottom a stack of wood burns. The caption reads, "From Limestone to Pure Lime. Cooking lime involved an enormous amount of work. Holiday Menor dug his frontier-style kiln into the edge of a dirt bank. Lined with bricks and rocks, the rounded chamber rose 30 feet. Limestone was loaded in from the top. Inside a second chamber housed the fire. A limestone "burn" required round-the-clock vigilance. Stacks of firewood were fed through a draw door to maintain white hot temperatures. Once the ashes were cooled, this pure lime could be packed in barrels."Close to the water's edge, near the bottom of the trail, just past a row of benches to the left of the walkway, is an open roofed structure covering an old boat-shaped, wooden pontoon. It is supported by a wooden frame and surrounded by a fence. The pontoon is about 30 feet long and is mostly intact, its sides covered with weathered green paint. A small sign at the front of the structure shows an historic photograph of an old automobile full of people being carried across the river on the ferry. Text reads, "Water Powered. Bill Menor began operating a ferry here in 1894. Menor's ferry provided one of the most important points of access to the land west of the Snake River until 1927. This wooden pontoon (ca. 1910) is the last remaining part of the ferry that operated during this period."A few yards past this structure, the walkway takes a switchback to the left, then back to the right to end at the water's edge. The paved landing is edged with a wooden curb and benches line the side nearest the bank. Across the wide river you can see the white-washed Menor's Ferry General Store and other buildin

title: Menors Ferry District
listingDescription: This homestead once belonged to William D. (Bill) Menor. He moved from Montana to the valley in 1894 and took up this homestead on the banks of the Snake River. His ferry became a vital crossing point for the early Jackson Hole settlers. In addition to the whitewashed cabin, general store, storage shed and smokehouse, the Menor homestead once included barns, a blacksmith shop, a garden, and irrigated hayfields and pastures. Take a self-guided walk through the area to learn so

images.altText: Historic image of Menors ferry carrying a covered wagon crossing the Snake River toward the west. The cabins and the Teton Range lie beyond.
images.caption: Historic Menors Ferry

bodyText: This homestead once belonged to William D. (Bill) Menor. He moved from Montana to the valley in 1894 and took up this homestead on the banks of the Snake River. His ferry became a vital crossing point for the early Jackson Hole settlers. In addition to the whitewashed cabin, general store, storage shed and smokehouse, the Menor homestead once included barns, a blacksmith shop, a garden, and irrigated hayfields and pastures. Take a self-guided walk through the area to learn some of the history of Jackson Hole and Grand Teton National Park.
audioDescription:
This sign sits at the edge of the paved parking lot. To its right, a paved path leads towards the Snake River with a sign indicating that the Menors Ferry Boat, the General Store, Maud Noble Cabin and Restrooms are located in that direction.

The wayside features an historic photograph of the Menors Ferry buildings, viewed from the far side of the river with the mountains rising behind them. Text on the panel reads, "View Bill Menor's original 1892 homestead along the Snake River. Follow the loop trail and learn about the early days of Jackson Hole.

In 1969, the National Register of Historic Places designated this place an historic district."

A map on the right side gives an overview of the area. North is behind you and slightly to your left. The "You are here" label indicates the position of this wayside at the edge of the parking lot at the bottom of the map. The Snake River runs across the map from left to right two-thirds of the way up. A dotted line labeled "Ferry Crossing" crosses the river in the center of the map. From your current location a dashed line shows the path extending up 50 yards to the restrooms. At that point, the path splits to form a triangular loop. The left hand path leads to Menor's General Store, smokehouse, storehouse and well. The right hand path leads to Maud Noble Cabin. The path connecting those two points runs along the river and passes the transportation barn.

Along the bottom of the sign are four blocks of text and photos. At the left, text reads, "Shop at the General Store. Shop at the Menor's Ferry General Store for turn-of-the-century style goods while viewing an exhibit of period furnishings and historic photographs (summer only)." The image shows sample goods, including a bottle of pop and a pottery pitcher.

The second block reads, "Learn About Park History. Visit Maud Noble Cabin to see exhibits on Jackson Hole history. Noble hosted a landmark meeting at this cabin in 1923." A photograph shows an historic photograph of the cabin.

The third block reads, "Ride Menor's Ferry. Join a ranger for a trip across the Snake River on the Menor's Ferry replica. Rangers operate the ferry from mid- to late summer depending on Snake River flows." A color photograph shows a park ranger wearing a life jacket, at the wheel of the ferry with the mountains in the background.

The right-most block reads, "Join a Ranger for a Guided Walk. During the summer rangers lead guided walks in the Menor's Ferry Historic District.
Dates and times are posted at this trailhead or see your park newspaper, the Teewinot for more information." A color photograph shows a group of people listening to a park ranger with the mountains in the background.

title: Menors General Store
listingDescription: Menors General Store is one wing of Bill Menor's original homestead cabin. The cabin was constructed in three distinct phases. Menor built the west wing in 1894 (the Tetons are to the west). Around 1895, he added the central section. The larger east wing was built around 1905. The west wing served as a bedroom and sitting room while the central section housed the kitchen and pantry. Menor opened a store in the east wing where settlers and travelers could purchase tobacco, co

images.altText: Front of Menors cabin and general store that are whitewashed. The Teton Range dominates the skyline above the cabin.
images.caption: Menors General Store

bodyText:
Menors General Store is one wing of Bill Menor's original homestead cabin. The cabin was constructed in three distinct phases. Menor built the west wing in 1894 (the Tetons are to the west). Around 1895, he added the central section. The larger east wing was built around 1905. The west wing served as a bedroom and sitting room while the central section housed the kitchen and pantry. Menor opened a store in the east wing where settlers and travelers could purchase tobacco, coffee, tea, sugar, flour, canned foods and some items of clothing. The store, ferry and blacksmith shop generated cash to supplement Menor's subsistence farming.

Except for a few items such as glass and nails, pioneers used local materials to construct shelters. Abundant stands of nearby lodgepole pine provided a convenient source of lumber. The rough-sawn boards of the central section indicate the presence of a sawmill in the valley around 1894. Menor painted his cabin with lime-based white-wash that he got from his brother, Holiday Menor who homesteaded across the river. Holiday Menor quarried lime from Blacktail Butte and prepared it in a kiln near the east landing of the ferry.
audioDescription:
This building is made of weathered whitewashed logs with chinking, finished in places with rough planking. The building is "T" shaped, with the entrance being at the end of one of the short arms. A porch extends across this part of the building, reached by two shallow steps. The rest of the building extends to the left. If you go through the door, the store's counter is in front of you, extending to the right and back to the rear of the store. Shelving lines the other walls. If you turn left in front of the counter, you can go down two steps and enter the attached cabin.

A small sign along the path leading to the store shows an historic photograph of Holiday Menor wearing white hat, dark vest and a close-cropped beard. The text reads, "Mean and Menor. Store owner Bill Menor, prone to swearing and a surly attitude, ran this general store in the early 1900s. Menor and his brother, Holiday, painted this building with whitewash from Holiday's limekiln. Referring to Bill, Holiday was known to say: "My partner's Mean, but I'm Menor.""

title: Millionaires and Poets
listingDescription: The BarBC regularly hosted celebrity visitors, including the Rockefeller family, William Faulkner, and Ernest Hemingway, who supposedly stayed in this cabin. Struthers Burt's friendship with Horace Albright, the superintendent of Yellowstone National Park, gradually brought Burt around to the idea of creating a national park in Jackson Hole. Burt became a strong conservationist in his own right and a key advocate for the future Grand Teton National Park.

images.altText: Two men in Western garb stand, arm in arm, in front of rustic cabins and fencing.
images.caption: Struthers Burt, at left, was the original founder and owner of the Bar BC with Horace Carncross. The man at right is unidentified. (Photo courtesy of the Jackson Hole Historical Society and Museum, 1958.0283.001)

bodyText: The BarBC regularly hosted celebrity visitors, including the Rockefeller family, William Faulkner, and Ernest Hemingway, who supposedly stayed in this cabin. Struthers Burt's friendship with Horace Albright, the superintendent of Yellowstone National Park, gradually brought Burt around to the idea of creating a national park in Jackson Hole. Burt became a strong conservationist in his own right and a key advocate for the future Grand Teton National Park, using his position of prominence to generate support for it. In 1930, he sold his share in the Bar BC to demonstrate the importance of preserving the valley as a park, and he and his family relocated to a ranch farther north. Burt also encouraged his friend, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., to contribute funds to buy up property in the valley to donate to the park, which was a critical step in the formation of Grand Teton National Park as we know today.
audioDescription: Host: The BarBC regularly hosted celebrity visitors, including the Rockefeller family, William Faulkner, and Ernest Hemingway, who supposedly stayed in this cabin. Struthers Burt's friendship with Horace Albright, the superintendent of Yellowstone National Park, gradually brought Burt around to the idea of creating a national park in Jackson Hole. Burt became a strong conservationist in his own right and a key advocate for the future Grand Teton National Park, using his position of prominence to generate support for it. In 1930, he sold his share in the Bar BC to demonstrate the importance of preserving the valley as a park, and he and his family relocated to a ranch farther north. Burt also encouraged his friend, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., to contribute funds to buy up property in the valley to donate to the park, which was a critical step in the formation of Grand Teton National Park as we know today. Excerpt from "Diary of a Dude Wrangler": "We have entertained millionaires and poets and artists, business men of every description...angels and those who weren't; people whose homes were in every part of the country from New York to San Francisco; Prohibitionists and Anti-Prohibitionists, Fundamentalists and Modernists, Reactionaries and Radicals, Futurists and Classicists; the bow-legged and fat-legged and spindle-shanked and knock-kneed; Englishmen and Frenchmen and Canadians."

title: Moose Entrance Station
listingDescription: Located one mile west of US 26/89/191 on the Teton Park Road, this entrance gate provides access to the central part of Grand Teton National Park. Visitors traveling north from Jackson may not realize that they have entered the park because they haven't passed through a gate. There is no fee to travel on US 26/89/191 through the park and east toward Dubois, WY.Just east of the gate is the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center and Dornans. The visitor center offers extensi

images.altText: Moose entrance gate with the Grand Teton in the distance
images.caption: Moose Entrance Gate

bodyText:
Located one mile west of US 26/89/191 on the Teton Park Road, this entrance gate provides access to the central part of Grand Teton National Park. Visitors traveling north from Jackson may not realize that they have entered the park because they haven't passed through a gate. There is no fee to travel on US 26/89/191 through the park and east toward Dubois, WY.

Just east of the gate is the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center and Dornans. The visitor center offers extensive visitor information and Dornans offers a variety of services. Past the gate, visitors climb the hill to Windy Point Turnout and a spectacular view of the Grand Teton.

Visitor Services

Rangers staff the entrance gate providing visitor information and selling entrance permits. The gate also posts campground availability. When no one is present, you may pick up a park newspaper (including a map) at the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center (summer). The Jackson Hole Greater Yellowstone Visitor Center in Jackson is open year-round. The gate is not staffed from November 1 through mid-December, but visitors are free to enter the park.

Name Origin

The small community of Moose was once known as Menors Ferry until the USPS requested the name change.

Moose frequent the nearby Snake River in summer and the sagebrush flats of the terraces above in late fall and early winter.

title: Moose Landing
listingDescription:
Location: Access the boat ramp west of park headquarters in Moose at the south end of the Teton Park Road. The launch also has a pulley system to assist.

Notes: The classic Snake River float through the park takes off the river at Moose and puts on upstream at Deadmans Bar. The river is home to moose, bald eagles, osprey and many other species. If you continue south of Moose, you leave the park but the scenery is still remarkable.

images.altText: Drift boat preparing to land at Moose with a boat lift above.
images.caption: Drift Boat at Moose Landing

bodyText:
The classic Snake River float through the park takes off the river at Moose and puts on upstream at Deadmans Bar. The river is home to moose, bald eagles, osprey, and many other species. If you continue south of Moose, you leave the park but the scenery is still remarkable.

Location

Access the boat ramp west of park headquarters in Moose at the south end of the Teton Park Road. 

Regulations

All boats including paddleboards launched in Grand Teton National Park must have a park permit. Purchase permits at the permits desk in the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center in Moose or the Colter Bay permits office. More information on park boat regulations.

Boat inspections required for all boats entering Wyoming between March 1 and November 30 for Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS). AIS inspection stations near Moose and Moran. Boat owners must buy a decal to support this program. Decals available at Snake River Anglers in Dornans or at the Colter Bay Marina; and other Wyoming Game and Fish outlets. More information on state boat regulations .
audioDescription:
The river here is reached down a wide, cement ramp which runs all the way to the edge of the water. The river is broad and filled with small stones with tree-covered banks on either side. Down river to the right is the Snake River Bridge. Across the river are glimpses of the buildings at Dornan's Service District.

Like all river launch access points there is a large, three-panel sign located close to the river providing information on safety, river regulations, and details on this section of the river.

The right hand panel reads, "Snake River Safety. The Snake River, wild and dynamic, provides challenges that rapidly test the skill of boaters. Braided channels and shifting log jams present difficulties found on few whitewater rivers.

"Boaters floating the Snake River must watch for areas of swift current, blocked channels, and hazards such as submerged rocks or logs, sweepers and strainers. River water remains cold throughout most of the year, increasing the risk of hypothermia.

"Review river updates posted below, but be aware that river channels change course frequently and boaters must take responsibility for safety."

Below this text there may be additional flyers posted with seasonally changing information.

The left hand panel reads, "Snake River Regulations. A National Park is a special place, created to protect resources while providing for visitor use and enjoyment; however, as more people explore the Snake River, increasing impacts harm fragile plant and animal communities. You can help prevent damage caused by human use by observing the following regulations.

"Boating. A park boating permits is required for all vessels floating the Snake River. Permits can be obtained at visitor centers. All vessels must carry a U.S. Coast Guard approved personal flotation device (PFD) properly fitted for each person on board. Motorboats and inner tubes are prohibited.

"Pets. Dogs and all other pets are not permitted on the river (or away from roads and parking areas) to avoid wildlife disturbance. Where permitted, pets must be leashed.

"Camping. Camping and fires are prohibited along the river.

"Resource Protection. Do not feed of disturb wildlife. You are disturbing an animal if you cause it to interrupt its natural activities or to move away from you. Stopping and bank use is prohibited in posted nesting areas. Collecting any natural or historic object(s) is prohibited.

"Fishing. A Wyoming state fishing license is required. Complete regulations can be obtained from visitor centers. Help preserve high quality angling for native wild fish."

An inset reads, " Stop Aquatic Hitchhikers! Prevent the transport of nuisance species. Clean all recreational equipment. Remove any visible mud, plants, fish or animals before transporting equipment."

The middle panel shows a map of the Snake River within Grand Teton National Park with the section from Moose Landing to South Park Boundary highlighted. Text reads, "Moose Landing to South Park Boundary. Advanced. Boaters must possess the ability to navigate fast moving water, braiding, and logjams; careful route-finding and channel selection can be critical.

"The park boundary extends five miles downriver from Moose on the west bank and two miles downriver on the east bank; there is no take out access at the park boundary. The next take out is at the Wilson Bridge, 14 miles downstream from Moose. In Case of Emergency Call 911! Nearest telephone Moose Headquarters Building."

title: Moose Pathway Access
listingDescription: The Moose pathway access is due south of the Post Office. Head north toward Jenny Lake through the sagebrush flats while enjoying spectacular views of the Teton Range. Or head east toward Moose Junction and explore the pathway toward Jackson or the Antelope Flats loop. Park in front of the Post Office or across the Teton Park Road at the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center. ABA compliant.

images.altText: Multi-use pathway access at Moose showing bike rack and pathway information sign.
images.caption: Moose Multi-use Pathway Access

bodyText:
The Moose pathway access is due south of the Post Office. Head north toward Jenny Lake through the sagebrush flats while enjoying spectacular views of the Teton Range. Or head east toward Moose Junction and explore the pathway toward Jackson or the Antelope Flats loop. Park in front of the Post Office or across the Teton Park Road at the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center. ABA compliant.

Regulations

Only use non-motorized forms of transportation on the multi-use pathway. Persons with physical disabilities may use battery-operated transportation. Do not access the pathway from dusk to dawn for your safety and wildlife's safety. Please do not walk your dog on the pathway. Guide dogs-used for the sole purpose of aiding a person with a physical disability-may travel on the pathway.
audioDescription:
There is a large, three-panel sign located near the pathway providing information on safety, park regulations and a map.

The center panel shows a map of the pathway between Moose Junction in the south and the southern end of Jenny Lake in the north. The pathway runs alongside the Teton Park Road for most of this stretch, only diverging slightly to the west as it approaches Jenny Lake Visitor Center.

The title on the right hand panel reads, "No Pets on Pathway" and shows a picture of a dog with the universal not-allowed symbol of a red circle with a line across it. The text reads, "PETS ARE NOT PERMITTED on the park pathway. Guide dogs-used for the sole purpose of aiding a person with physical disability-may travel on the pathway. The pathway travels through sensitive wildlife areas.

"Why Are Pets Not Allowed? For the wildlife and for your safety.
o Wildlife such as bears, wolves or coyotes may be drawn to pets and their owners.
o A surprise encounter with wildlife may result in death or injury to pets, wildlife or visitors.
o Pets may escape and quickly become prey.
o Dogs cause the same stress responses in prey species (such as elk and pronghorn) as predators do.
oTransmittable diseases, such as parvovirus, from infected feces may live in the soil for months, passing on to wildlife.

"WHERE CAN PETS GO?
"OUTSIDE THE PARK
o Jackson Hole Community Pathways except on the National Elk Refuge.
o Bridger-Teton National Forest trails-Shadow Mountain, Gros Ventre River, Snow King, Cache Creek, Phillips Canyon and Teton Pass.
o Snake River dike, at the intersection of highways WY 22 & 390 in Wilson.

"INSIDE THE PARK
"In general, leashed pets may go anywhere a car may go-roads and road shoulders, campgrounds, picnic areas, and parking lots. Pets must be in control and restrained on a leash no longer than six feet in length."

At the bottom of the panel are photographs of a bull moose and a male sage grouse, its large white chest puffed up. The text reads, "SAGEBRUSH COMMUNITY. The drought-tolerant plants of the sagebrush community thrive despite porous, cobbly soils and intense sunlight. These flowering plants form one of the most colorful and diverse communities in the park. Sagebrush provides a mosaic of food and shelter for a variety of animals."

The panel on the left is titled "Protect Your Park." In a light green color block at the top left there is a photograph of two people on bicycles on the path with Grand Teton in the background. Text reads, "How to Ride. Only NON-MOTORIZED METHODS of transportation are permitted on the multi-use pathway. Persons with physical disabilities may use electric and battery-operated transportation. Horses are not permitted on the pathway, except on the Snake River bridge in Moose.
o Travel single file in the right-side lane; share the pathway.
o Notify other recreators before you pass. Be aware of others passing you.
o The use of portable audio devices is strongly discouraged.
o Obey all traffic signs. Yield to all vehicles.
o Yield to slower recreators.
o Wear a helmet.
o Stay on paved pathway; no shortcutting through vegetation.
Absolutely no pets allowed. Respect the rights of all users."

In the center of the panel is a photograph of a small herd of pronghorn . The caption reads, "Help wildlife thrive. NEVER FEED, APPROACH OR HARASS WILDLIFE-especially large mammals. Stay at least 100 yards away from bears and wolves, and 25 yards from other animals. Be prepared for wildlife interactions; be prepared to stop."

At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of two bears standing in snow at the edge of a pond, drinking. The caption reads, "Be Bear Aware. Grizzly and black bears may become aggressive when surprised or in defense of young. Stay alert and make bears aware of your presence. Follow food storage regulations: never leave your backpack, pannier or any item with food unattended. Carry and know how to use bear spray."

There are two smaller photograph in a border down the right side of the panel. The first one shows an elk with a full set of antlers. The caption reads, "When to Ride. The multi-use pathway is CLOSED from dusk to dawn for wildlife and public safety."

The bottom photo shows a single tree backlit by a sun low in the sky. The caption reads, "Leave No Trace. The park PROHIBITS PICKING, COLLECTING OR DESTROYING park resources. Leave all plants, animals and artifacts as you found them for other visitors to enjoy. Stay on the designated pathway to help preserve the park."

title: Moose Post Office
listingDescription: The Moose Post Office across the Teton Park Road from the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center, offers all USPS services but has limited hours.

images.altText: Front of the Moose Post Office with flag and blue drop box
images.caption: Moose Post Office

bodyText:
The Moose Post Office across the Teton Park Road from the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center, offers all USPS services but has limited hours. For hours and addtional information check the Moose Post Office web page.

Name Origin

The small community of Moose was once known as Menors Ferry until the USPS requested the name change.

Moose frequent the nearby Snake River in summer and the sagebrush flats of the terraces above in late fall and early winter.

title: Moran Entrance Station
listingDescription: Located a quarter mile north of Moran Junction on US 89/191/287, this entrance gate provides access to northern Grand Teton National Park and on north to Yellowstone. Visitors traveling north from Jackson may not realize that they have entered the park because they haven't passed through a gate. There is no fee to travel on US 26/89/191 through the park and east toward Dubois, WY.Past the gate, visitors traverse sagebrush meadows and open lodgepole forests approaching Jackson

images.altText: Entrance kiosk with car and motorcycle waiting at Moran Entrance gate
images.caption: Moran Entrance Gate with Visitors

bodyText:
Located a quarter mile north of Moran Junction on US 89/191/287, this entrance gate provides access to northern Grand Teton National Park and on north to Yellowstone. Visitors traveling north from Jackson may not realize that they have entered the park because they haven't passed through a gate. There is no fee to travel on US 26/89/191 through the park and east toward Dubois, WY.

Past the gate, visitors traverse sagebrush meadows and open lodgepole forests approaching Jackson Lake. A popular spot for wildlife viewing and incredible views of Mount Moran, Oxbow Bend, is two and a half miles west of the gate.

Visitor Services

Rangers staff the entrance gate providing visitor information and selling entrance permits. The gate also posts campground availability and fee information. When no one is present, you may pick up a park newspaper (including a map) in front of the Colter Bay Visitor Center. The gate is not staffed from November 1 through mid-December, but you may access the park.

Name Origin

Landscape artist Thomas Moran accompanied the 1872 Hayden expedition into Yellowstone. Moran produced many sketches and watercolors introducing the Greater Yellowstone area to Easterners. He visited the west side of the Teton Range, but never saw the mountain named for him.

title: Mormon Row
listingDescription: The buildings on Mormon Row tell the story of a once vibrant community. The Homestead Act of 1862 promised 160 acres to any person willing to build a house and cultivate the land for 5 years. This act enabled the settlement to come together. The promise of land eventually drew settlers to Mormon Row, originally known as Grovont in the 1890s. Healthy sagebrush indicated richer soil and drew the first Mormon families with hopes of beginning a new life. constructed of ranch

images.altText: TA Moulton barn with Teton Range beyond and cottonwood trees in the fields.
images.caption: T.A. Moulton Barn

bodyText:
The buildings on Mormon Row tell the story of a once vibrant community. The Homestead Act of 1862 promised 160 acres to any person willing to build a house and cultivate the land for 5 years. This act enabled the settlement to come together. The promise of land eventually drew settlers to Mormon Row, originally known as Grovont in the 1890s. Healthy sagebrush indicated richer soil and drew the first Mormon families with hopes of beginning a new life. They constructed of ranches, homes, a church and a school, forming a true community.

Many Mormon Row settlers sold their land and moved on by the mid-1900s. This land was later incorporated into Grand Teton National Park. They moved into Jackson and other surrounding communities. Now we see a landscape of sagebrush, cottonwood trees and quaking aspen. As we watch bison and pronghorn roaming the sagebrush flats, imagine the grazing cattle and hayfields filling the horizon.

Name Origin

Members from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints spread north from Utah and homesteaded on the east side of Blacktail Butte in the late 1880s. Known as Mormons, they settled the community known as Grovont and used their collective efforts to survive in the valley's harsh environment.

title: Mormon Row North Parking
listingDescription: Access the northern portion of Mormon Row from a small parking area just north of the intersection of Antelope Flats Road and Mormon Row. The adjacent homestead with the prominent Pink House was once owned by John and Bertha Moulton. A short walk north will lead to the Thomas Murphy homestead. Enjoy the rich history of the Mormon Row area.

images.altText: Vehicles parked in the parking lot north of the junction between Antelope Flats and Mormon Row roads. The Pink House and the Teton Range are visible.
images.caption: North Parking at Mormon Row

bodyText: Access the northern portion of Mormon Row from a small parking area just north of the intersection of Antelope Flats Road and Mormon Row. The adjacent homestead with the prominent Pink House was once owned by John and Bertha Moulton. A short walk north will lead to the Thomas Murphy homestead. Enjoy the rich history of the Mormon Row area.

title: Mormon Row South Parking
listingDescription: Enjoy the rich history of the Mormon Row Historic District. Parking south of Antelope Flats Road on Mormon Row provides access to the southern homesteads including the iconic T.A. Moulton barn, the Chambers homestead, the Thomas Perry Homestead, and the Clark and Veda Moulton homestead. These homesteads were part of the town once known as Grovont. Today, only the Clark and Veda Moulton is occupied seasonally.

images.altText: Visitors unloading from a van at the South Mormon Row Parking area with a vault toilet to the left.
images.caption: South Mormon Row

bodyText: Enjoy the rich history of the Mormon Row Historic District. Parking south of Antelope Flats Road on Mormon Row provides access to the southern homesteads including the iconic T.A. Moulton barn, the Chambers homestead, the Thomas Perry Homestead, and the Clark and Veda Moulton homestead. These homesteads were part of the town once known as Grovont. Today, only the Clark and Veda Moulton is occupied seasonally.

title: Mount Moran Turnout
listingDescription: Mount Moran, named for the famous landscape painter Thomas Moran, is the dominant peak of the northern Teton Range. The mountain also reflects all the geologic forces that formed the Teton Range. Ancient igneous and metamorphic rocks comprise the mountain core, sedimentary rocks drape the summit and Little Ice Age glaciers flank the slopes. The most noticeable feature is a vein (or dike) of black diabase that slices vertically across the east face of Mount Moran.

images.altText: Wayside sign for Mount Moran Turnout with sagebrush in foreground and Mount Moran in background.
images.caption: Mount Moran

bodyText:
Mount Moran, named for the famous landscape painter Thomas Moran, is the dominant peak of the northern Teton Range. The mountain also reflects all the geologic forces that formed the Teton Range. Ancient igneous and metamorphic rocks comprise the mountain core, sedimentary rocks drape the summit and Little Ice Age glaciers flank the slopes. The most noticeable feature is a vein (or dike) of black diabase that slices vertically across the east face of Mount Moran. The feature appears man-made, but molten magma squeezed into cracks in the existing bedrock almost a billion years ago. Later, erosion stripped away the surrounding rock allowing the dike to protrude.

Name Origin

Landscape artist Thomas Moran accompanied the 1872 Hayden expedition into Yellowstone. Moran produced many sketches and watercolors introducing the Greater Yellowstone area to Easterners. He visited the west side of the Teton Range, but never saw the mountain named for him.
audioDescription: This wayside sits at the edge of a cement semicircle next to the paved parking area. The curb has wheelchair access in the middle. The sign looks out over a flat sagebrush covered meadow with Mount Moran beyond. The background of the sign has a photograph of Mount Moran, the rocks tinged red by the sun with snowy patches. Text on the right side of the panel reads, "Mount Moran. Mt. Moran reflects all the geologic forces shaping the Teton Range. Formed of a massive block of metamorphic gneiss, cut by dikes of igneous granite and diabase, capped by sedimentary sandstone, and flanked by glaciers, this formidable peak dominates the park's northern skyline. "The gneiss and granite are among the oldest rocks in North America, 2.7 and 2.5 billion years old respectively. These resistant rocks form the core of the Teton Range. The vertical "Black Dike" of 775 million year old diabase is about 150 feet wide and juts from the mountain's face because the surrounding gneiss has eroded away." An inset photo in the lower left hand corner shows a close view of the tan-colored rocky summit of the mountain with a brown vertical strip down the middle. The caption reads, "Tan sandstone caps the summit of this massive peak the remnant of a 510 million year-old beach that stretched for hundreds of miles north and south of here. Sandstone overlies the Black Dike and other ancient igneous and metamorphic rocks." To the right of that another photo shows an icy patch below the summit, labeled "Falling Ice Glacier." The caption reads, "Five glaciers - Falling Ice, Skillet and Triple - flank Mount Moran. These glaciers formed during a cool period called the Little Ice Age that ended around 1850 AD. Over the past 40 years, the park's glaciers have shrunk by more than 20 percent due to our changing climate."

title: Mountain View Turnout
listingDescription: The Teton Range appears unchanging, but the opposite is true. The rocks found in the mountains formed hundreds of millions to billions of years ago. Movement on the Teton fault generated earthquakes that began to lift the mountains less than 10 million years ago. Ice age glaciers carved canyons and lakes. All the while, erosion due to water, wind and ice continue to sculpt the range, and any day another earthquake could violently change the landscape.

images.altText: Mountain View Turnout wayside surrounded by sagebrush. View of Mt. St. John to the left and Mt. Moran to the right.
images.caption: Young, Restless and Still Rising

bodyText: The Teton Range appears unchanging, but the opposite is true. The rocks found in the mountains formed hundreds of millions to billions of years ago. Movement on the Teton fault generated earthquakes that began to lift the mountains less than 10 million years ago. Ice age glaciers carved canyons and lakes. All the while, erosion due to water, wind and ice continue to sculpt the range, and any day another earthquake could violently change the landscape.
audioDescription: This wayside sits at the edge of a paved semicircle with an accessible ramp from the parking area. The sign looks out over a meadow dotted with patches of dark conifers and the flat summit and rocky sides of Mount Moran in the background. The background of the sign has a photograph of Mount Moran, the rocks tinged red by the sun with patches of snow and glaciers on its slopes. Text on the left side of the panel reads, "Young, Restless and Still Rising. Imagine the Teton Range and the valley in front of you like two parts of a giant hinge. The Earth's crust stretches and breaks into two blocks along the 40-mile long Teton fault. Fractures generate large earthquakes along the fault. The western block hinges up and becomes the Teton Range." "The eastern block tilts down and forms the valley. As the mountains rise, wind, water, and ice wear down the jagged skyline and erode away sandstone and limestone layers from the east side of the range. The landscape continues to change. Geoscientists predict future earthquakes up to a 7.5 magnitude." In the bottom left is an illustration showing the Teton Range with an orange line along its eastern base indicating the line of the Teton Fault. A vertical cutaway shows the land underneath the range rising and the land to the east subsiding. In the bottom right hand corner is a drawing showing a close-up view of Mount St. John and Mount Moran with the Teton Fault line at their base marked in yellow. A caption reads, "Young Range, Old Rocks. The Teton Range is one of the youngest mountain ranges in North America, but the rocks are some of the oldest. The stretching-cracking-tilting that formed the Tetons began about nine million years ago. In contrast, geologic forces squeezed the Earth's crust and thrust up the Rockies ending around 55 million years ago."

title: Mud Flats Picnic Area
listingDescription: Mudflats picnic area only has one table, but the view of the Teton Range is spectacular. The name arises from the mud flats that become exposed when water releases from Jackson Lake dam lower the lake level toward the natural pool level. At that point the Snake River carves through the exposed muddy lake-bottom sediments.

images.altText: Visitors at Mud Flats picnic area enjoying the fall colors of the aspens on the edge of Jackson Lake. The Teton Range stretches to the south across the lake.
images.caption: Fall colors at Mud Flats

bodyText:
Mudflats picnic area only has one table, but the view of the Teton Range is spectacular. The name arises from the mud flats that become exposed when water releases from Jackson Lake dam lower the lake level toward the natural pool level. At that point the Snake River carves through the exposed muddy lake-bottom sediments.

Name Origin

The water in the northern end of Jackson Lake is a reservoir. When water is released from the dam, the water recedes south toward the natural lake leaving behind lake bottom mud cut by the Snake River.

title: Murie Homestead Cabin
listingDescription: In 1945, the Muries bought the STS Ranch, with Adolph and Louise living in the original building now known as the Homestead. In 1926, the Murie brothers began their master's degree programs at the University of Michigan in the young science of ecology. While Olaus' studies were a one-year break in his Biological Survey work, Adolph completed his Ph.D. with a firm commitment to the value of all wildlife.

images.altText: The Murie Ranch Homestead Cabin. A larger log cabin with a small front porch and cobblestone chimney. Eight brightly painted metal chairs are in a circle in front of the cabin.
images.caption: Homestead Cabin

bodyText:
In 1945, the Muries bought the STS Ranch, with Adolph and Louise living in the original building now known as the Homestead. In 1926, the Murie brothers began their master's degree programs at the University of Michigan in the young science of ecology. While Olaus' studies were a one-year break in his Biological Survey work, Adolph completed his Ph.D. with a firm commitment to the value of all wildlife.

Through his career as a wildlife biologist, Adolph's research challenged long-standing values in wildlife management. His groundbreaking studies on carnivores opened the door to our modern understanding of predator-prey relationships. His 1937 study of coyotes in Yellowstone National Park was the first serious predator study in the park service's history. His findings ignited a controversy by stating the value of all species and condemning the ongoing practice of killing coyotes in the park.

Adolph served as Grand Teton National Park's only biologist throughout the 1950s. Even as they held long assignments in Alaska and other places during Adolph's thirty-year Park Service career, the Homestead cabin at the Ranch remained Adolph and Louise's home base.
audioDescription: This building is a long, low log cabin with a grey metal roof, set on a stone foundation. A wide stone chimney rises towards the back of the roof, right of center. The walls are built of smooth logs with small wooden poles used as chinking. The ends of the logs are painted green. The covered entrance is in the center of the building. The windows are small and located just under the roofline - two on the right side and one on the left side of the door. At the far left end of the building is a section where the top half of the wall is screened in. On the wall to the right of the door are two plaques. The top one is of metal and reads, "Original Buster Estes Homestead Cabin, 1920-1945. Home of Adolph and Louise Murie, 1945-1974. Restoration by The Murie Center. Exterior funded by The National Park Foundation through a generous gift from Aurora Foods, Inc. Log Cabin Brand." The sign below reads, "The Murie Ranch Historic District was listed in the National Register of Historic Places on August 24, 1998, due to its importance to the American Conservation Movement. Preservation of the Murie Ranch Historic District is being supported in part by a federal Save America's Treasures award administered by the National Park Service, Department of the Interior. Thanks go to the patrons of The Murie Center for supporting this rehabilitation effort to recreate the magic of the early years on the Murie Ranch and continue to influence the conservation movement."

title: Murie Ranch
listingDescription: Brothers Olaus and Adolph Murie married sisters Margaret and Louise and acquired the STS Ranch in 1945. The Ranch, later known as the Murie Ranch, became the setting for their research, writings, and gatherings. Through science, art and writing, the Muries captured and personified the spirit of wilderness, inspiring generations to visit the Murie Ranch and become advocates of wild places. Olaus and Adolph Murie were pioneering wildlife biologists.

images.altText: Small log cabin serving as office for the Murie Ranch of Teton Science Schools. Brochure box for self-guided tour to the right of the office and a boulder with a plaque designating the ranch as a National Historic Landmark to the left.
images.caption: Murie Ranch Office

bodyText:
Brothers Olaus and Adolph Murie married sisters Margaret and Louise and acquired the STS Ranch in 1945. The Ranch, later known as the Murie Ranch, became the setting for their research, writings, and gatherings. Through science, art and writing, the Muries captured and personified the spirit of wilderness, inspiring generations to visit the Murie Ranch and become advocates of wild places. Olaus and Adolph Murie were pioneering wildlife biologists. Their innovative studies helped move wildlife management toward holistic management of ecosystems rather than the promotion of individual species.

Today the Murie Ranch is part of the Teton Science Schools offering extended learning opportunities for adults. For more information please visit the Murie Ranch website.

title: Murie Residence
listingDescription: In 1945 the Murie families jumped at the opportunity to purchase this ranch from Buster and Frances Estes. Buster was a local cowboy while Frances came from a wealthy Philadelphia family. She first came to Jackson Hole as a guest at the Bar B C Dude Ranch where Buster worked.. Olaus and Mardy moved to the ranch one year later and lived in the Alatna cabin before purchasing the adjacent Woodbury home in 1947.

images.altText: Murie Residence cabin tan logs with an covered inset porch. Ends of logs painted green. Aspen tree in front and elk antlers.
images.caption: Mardy & Olaus Murie House

bodyText: In 1945 the Murie families jumped at the opportunity to purchase this ranch from Buster and Frances Estes. Buster was a local cowboy while Frances came from a wealthy Philadelphia family. She first came to Jackson Hole as a guest at the Bar B C Dude Ranch where Buster worked.. Olaus and Mardy moved to the ranch one year later and lived in the Alatna cabin before purchasing the adjacent Woodbury home in 1947. The STS Ranch provided accommodations for many gatherings of the Wilderness Society during Olaus' leadership and provided a home base for writers and activists. With numerous cabins from the dude ranch days, every summer saw many guests, relatives and friends. As Mardy observed: "every conservationist or fiend of a conservationist came to stay."
audioDescription: This building is a rectangular log structure with a grey metal roof. The house is deeper than wide. The walls are built of smooth logs with small wooden poles used as chinking. The ends of the logs are painted green. The peak of the roof is centered over the front of the house. The center third of the front wall is recessed to form a deep porch enclosed on three sides. On the front on either side of the porch is a set of double-sash windows. Two low steps lead up to the porch. There are rounds tables on either side of the porch with wooden chairs for sitting. Hanging above the entrance to the porch a wooden sign reads, "Mardy and Olaus Murie House." The entrance door is at the back of the porch flanked by two picture windows.

title: Olaus Murie's Studio
listingDescription: In 1927, Olaus and Mardy Murie moved to Jackson Hole where the federal government assigned him to study the valley's famous elk herd. He published his extensive field research in the book, The Elk of North America. Based on his scientific understanding of elk movements, Olaus lobbied for an expansion of Grand Teton national Pak to account for elk migration through Jackson Hole. Eventually, park boundaries were expanded to include, not just the rugged mountains, but also the v

images.altText: Historic image of Olaus Murie painting in his studio. Standing at an easel.
images.caption: Olaus Murie in his Studio

bodyText:
In 1927, Olaus and Mardy Murie moved to Jackson Hole where the federal government assigned him to study the valley's famous elk herd. He published his extensive field research in the book, The Elk of North America. Based on his scientific understanding of elk movements, Olaus lobbied for an expansion of Grand Teton national Pak to account for elk migration through Jackson Hole. Eventually, park boundaries were expanded to include, not just the rugged mountains, but also the valley floor.
During this time, Olaus also conducted studies of coyotes and mice and continued drawing and painting wildlife. He wrote numerous scientific papers and books, one being, "Field Guide to Animal Tracks" (1954) which is still in print today and a valued tracking classic.
audioDescription: This building is a small log structure with a grey metal roof. The walls are built of smooth logs with small wooden poles used as chinking. The ends of the logs are painted green. The single door is placed in the middle of the front with two sets of double-sash windows on either side. A low porch supported by log posts runs along the entire front of the building. Two low steps lead up to the porch.

title: Outhouse
listingDescription: Bill Menors Outhouse.

images.altText: Brown log sided outhouse, only a doors width on all sides with a sloping roof.

bodyText: Bill Menors Outhouse.

title: Oxbow Bend Turnout
listingDescription:
Oxbow Bend provides a stunning view of the northern Teton Range especially during fall. Mount Moran towers in the distance and golden-leafed aspen trees flank this slow-moving bend in the Snake River. A calm morning may also capture a reflection of Mount Moran mirrored in the water.

Visitors frequent this turnout to catch a glimpse of wildlife. Moose, beaver, muskrat, river otters and white pelicans are common, but others such as bears and trumpeter swans make appearances. Enjoy the view or the wildlife from one of the most popular turnouts in the park.

images.altText: View of Mount Moran reflected in the Oxbow Bend with golden-leafed aspen trees in the middle-ground. A wayside about American Indian culture is in front of a photographer.
images.caption: 11,000 Summers in the Tetons

bodyText:
Oxbow Bend provides a stunning view of the northern Teton Range especially during fall. Mount Moran towers in the distance and golden-leafed aspen trees flank this slow-moving bend in the Snake River. A calm morning may also capture a reflection of Mount Moran mirrored in the water.

Visitors frequent this turnout to catch a glimpse of wildlife. Moose, beaver, muskrat, river otters and white pelicans are common, but others such as bears and trumpeter swans make appearances. Enjoy the view or the wildlife from one of the most popular turnouts in the park.

Name Origin

A bend in the Snake River that resembles the bow under an oxen yoke. Geologically speaking, an oxbow forms when a meander channel is cut off from the main stream forming a pond.
audioDescription:
This turnout sits on top of a high bank overlooking the Snake River below. The river sweeps away from you in both directions, forming a sharp bend called an oxbow. The other side of the river is thickly wooded. The side you are on has more open flat land with shrubs and a few trees on the bank in front of you. There is a large meadow to the left, to the right is a stand of Aspen trees. In the distance to the right Mt Moran towers over the landscape.

There are two wayside signs along this turnout. The one on the left has a large picture of two moose in the river, one with antlers. Text reads, "Spot Any Wetlands Wildlife? This oxbow bend in the Snake River provides food, water, shelter, and nesting sites for wildlife. Plants thrive in the sediments and shallow waters. Moose browse on willows and tender plants. Mergansers, teals, and white pelicans feed on aquatic life. Playful otters swim and dive. Ospreys and bald eagles soar above the river searching for food. Beavers gnaw on saplings to build lodges or dams. In the quiet backwater, cutthroat trout rise to the surface, and great blue herons fish in the shallows."

In the upper right corner is an inset photo of an American White pelican. In the lower left are 4 inset photos, left to right of two beavers, Trumpeter swans and Canada geese, a river otter, and a cutthroat trout.

Towards the right end of the paved area another wayside is titled "11,000 Summers in the Tetons." The background shows a black and white picture of Indians on Jackson Lake, a 1930s oil painting by Herbert A. Collins. The painting shows about fifteen American Indian figures, men, women and children at a camp on the edge of a lake with the mountains in the background. Some of the people are around a large campfire; others dress an antelope carcass. Two tee-pees stand on the edge of the lake. Text reads, "This slow-moving channel of the Snake River at Oxbow Bend sustains many different animals. Every year thousands of visitors come here to see them. Like you, Indian tribes such as Shoshone, Bannock, Blackfoot, Crow, Nez Perce and Gros Ventre have been drawn to places like this for more than 11,000 years. American Indians ventured into this valley as glaciers receded. They came to Jackson Hole in the spring to hunt game, harvest roots and berries. They collected soapstone for bowls, obsidian for projectile points and quartzite for tools and roasting hearths. As winter approached they left their summer home in the Teton Range for warmer places."

title: Pacific Creek Landing
listingDescription: Location: Access the boat ramp just north of Moran Entrance Gate on US 89/191/287. Drive beyond the picnic area to the river. Notes: Pacific Creek Landing is the takeout for the easiest section of the Snake River through the park--Dam to Pacific Creek. The landing is also the put-in for the second easiest section of river--Pacific Creek to Deadmans Bar. The Snake River is famous for scenery, fishing and wildlife! The picnic area offers limited amenities, but no water. Acce

images.altText: Visitors fishing from two drift boats on the Snake River near Pacific Landing
images.caption: Fishing near Pacific Landing

bodyText:
Location: Access the boat ramp just north of Moran Entrance Gate on US 89/191/287. Drive beyond the picnic area to the river.

Notes: Pacific Creek Landing is the takeout for the easiest section of the Snake River through the park--Dam to Pacific Creek. The landing is also the put-in for the second easiest section of river--Pacific Creek to Deadmans Bar. The Snake River is famous for scenery, fishing and wildlife! The picnic area offers limited amenities, but no water. Access to Pacific Creek Landing will be limited Summer 2020. The launch is expected to close after August 31, 2020.

Regulations

All boats including paddleboards launched in Grand Teton National Park must have a park permit. Purchase permits at the permits desk in the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center in Moose or the Colter Bay permits office. More information on park boat regulations.

Boat inspections required for all boats entering Wyoming between March 1 and November 30 for Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS). AIS check station near Moose and Moran. Boat owners must buy a decal to support this program. More information on state boat regulations .

Name Origin

The headwaters of Pacific Creek are on Two Ocean Plateau in Yellowstone National Park on the Continental Divide. The stream flows down a ridge and splits. One branch becomes Pacific Creek flowing into the Snake River and westward. The other branch becomes Atlantic Creek flowing into the Yellowstone River and eastward.
audioDescription:
The sand and gravel boat launch to the river's edge here is almost flat. If the water is low, the edge of the river extends into a broad sandy area. The river curves slightly away from you in both directions and depending upon seasonal flow there may small rapids. Across the river is a stand of dark conifer trees.

Like all river launch access points there is a large, three-panel sign located close to the river providing information on safety, river regulations, and details on this section of the river.

The left hand panel reads, "Snake River Safety. The Snake River, wild and dynamic, provides challenges that rapidly test the skill of boaters. Braided channels and shifting log jams present difficulties found on few whitewater rivers.

"Boaters floating the Snake River must watch for areas of swift current, blocked channels, and hazards such as submerged rocks or logs, sweepers and strainers. River water remains cold throughout most of the year, increasing the risk of hypothermia.
"Review river updates posted below, but be aware that river channels change course frequently and boaters must take responsibility for safety."

Below this text there may be additional flyers posted with seasonally changing information.

The right hand panel reads, "Snake River Regulations. A National Park is a special place, created to protect resources while providing for visitor use and enjoyment; however, as more people explore the Snake River, increasing impacts harm fragile plant and animal communities. You can help prevent damage caused by human use by observing the following regulations.

"Boating. A park boating permits is required for all vessels floating the Snake River. Permits can be obtained at visitor centers. All vessels must carry a U.S. Coast Guard approved personal flotation device (PFD) properly fitted for each person on board. Motorboats and inner tubes are prohibited.

"Pets. Dogs and all other pets are not permitted on the river (or away from roads and parking areas) to avoid wildlife disturbance. Where permitted, pets must be leashed.

"Camping. Camping and fires are prohibited along the river.

"Resource Protection. Do not feed of disturb wildlife. You are disturbing an animal if you cause it to interrupt its natural activities or to move away from you. Stopping and bank use is prohibited in posted nesting areas. Collecting any natural or historic object(s) is prohibited.

"Fishing. A Wyoming state fishing license is required. Complete regulations can be obtained from visitor centers. Help preserve high quality angling for native wild fish."

An inset reads, " Stop Aquatic Hitchhikers! Prevent the transport of nuisance species. Clean all recreational equipment. Remove any visible mud, plants, fish or animals before transporting equipment."

The middle panel shows a map of the Snake River within Grand Teton National Park with the section from Pacific Creek Landing to Deadman's Bar highlighted. Text reads, "Intermediate. This section of the river drops in elevation significantly, increasing the current. Braided channels make route-finding difficult and require skill and constant awareness. In Case of Emergency Call 911! The nearest telephone is at Buffalo Fork Ranger Station Â¼ mile east on HWY 89/287."

title: Park Headquarters
listingDescription: Park headquarters is north of the Craig Thomas Discover & Visitor Center in Moose. This facility houses most park operations, but is not open to the public.

images.altText: Superintendent Vela standing next to park headquarters sign with the building in the background.
images.caption: Superintendent Vela at Headquarters

bodyText: Park headquarters is north of the Craig Thomas Discover & Visitor Center in Moose. This facility houses most park operations, but is not open to the public.

title: Path of the Pronghorn Turnout
listingDescription: Pronghorn and bison frequent the sagebrush meadows before you during the summer. Pronghorn are the fastest land animal in North America sprinting to speeds of 60 mph (96 kph). As winter sets in, pronghorn (also known as pronghorn antelope) migrate southeast on the second-longest terrestrial migration in North America. They encounter many obstacles along their route including fences and roads. Studying their migration has led to efforts to protect this pathway.

images.altText: Path of the pronghorn wayside with view looking across sagebrush meadows of Anetlope Flats toward Blacktail Butte and the Teton Range
images.caption: Path of the Pronghorn with Teton Range

bodyText:
Pronghorn and bison frequent the sagebrush meadows before you during the summer. Pronghorn are the fastest land animal in North America sprinting to speeds of 60 mph (96 kph). As winter sets in, pronghorn (also known as pronghorn antelope) migrate southeast on the second-longest terrestrial migration in North America. They encounter many obstacles along their route including fences and roads. Studying their migration has led to efforts to protect this pathway.

Name Origin

Pronghorn ( Antilocapra americana ) also known as antelope are the fastest terrestrial animal in North America, and have the second longest migration! They can sprint 60 mph and sustain over 40 mph for one mile! After spending summers in the sagebrush flats along the base of the Teton Range, they migrate up to 150 miles south and east up the Gros Ventre drainage and down past Pinedale, WY. Fences are a significant barrier to migration. Pronghorn are reluctant to jump fences and will generally crawl under them.
audioDescription:
This wayside overlooks a sweeping sagebrush flat flanked by hills and mountains in the distance. The left side of the sign shows a map of the pronghorn migration route. At the bottom right of the sign is a photo of a pronghorn's head, clearly showing the horns with a sharp curve at the ends. The caption reads, "Pronghorn are named for their forked, hollow horns, being the only animal to annually shed a branched horn. Pronghorn are the fastest land mammal in North America."

The main text in the upper right of the sign reads, "The pronghorn that summer in Jackson Hole make the longest terrestrial mammal migration remaining in the contiguous United States. Pronghorn use migration as an adaptation for surviving the long Wyoming winters by moving to where they can find food and avoid deep snow.

"The southward fall migration usually occurs during November, with animals returning to northern summer ranges in late April and May. Round-trip migration distances for this her range from 200 - 300 miles annually.

"A Threatened Migration? History has shown that migrations are fragile. Three quarters of pronghorn migrations in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem have already been lost to land development. Further development could threaten the future of this remaining corridor."

The map on the left shows a red area covering the eastern side of Grand Teton National Park marking the pronghorn's summer range. This wayside is located on the eastern edge of that range, about two-thirds of the way down. From this point the migration path is shown as a red line moving east and then south, into the Green River Basin past the intersection of US Highways 189 and 191. There the winter range is shown as another red area. The caption reads, "Jackson Hole pronghorn migrate along an ancient corridor to Green River basin wintering areas near Pinedale, Wyoming. Archaeological evidence of pronghorn at Trapper's Point dates back 6,000 years."

Smaller photos show a small herd in a meadow during summer and a larger group moving through belly-deep snow in winter.

title: Potholes Turnout
listingDescription: This odd stand of conifer trees took root in a depression within the sagebrush flats. Locals called these depressions "potholes" while other regions of the country call these features "kettles." As ice-age glaciers retreated, blocks of ice dropped from the glacier's face onto the valley floor. Sediment carried by meltwater buried the ice. Later, the ice melted leaving behind a depression. Water may pond in pothole, and spring runoff and wind may carry sediment into the hole. With time, a pothole develops a micro-ecosystem supporting trees and accompanying wildlife-providing a shady respite from the exposure of the sagebrush flats.

images.altText: Looking past the Pothole Wayside sign toward a stand of conifer trees surrounded by sagebrush
images.caption: Potholes Turnout

bodyText:
This odd stand of conifer trees took root in a depression within the sagebrush flats. Locals called these depressions "potholes" while other regions of the country call these features "kettles." As ice-age glaciers retreated, blocks of ice dropped from the glacier's face onto the valley floor. Sediment carried by meltwater buried the ice. Later, the ice melted leaving behind a depression. Water may pond in pothole, and spring runoff and wind may carry sediment into the hole. With time, a pothole develops a micro-ecosystem supporting trees and accompanying wildlife-providing a shady respite from the exposure of the sagebrush flats.

Name Origin

Potholes, also known as kettles, are depressions in the glacial outwash plain. A pothole forms when an ice chunk breaks off a retreating glacier and lands on the plain. Run-off sediments deposit around the ice and may bury the ice. After the ice melts, a depression is left behind. This depression forms a micro-environment trapping moisture and dust allowing trees to take root.
audioDescription:
This wayside sits at the edge of the paved parking area and looks roughly southward over a flat plain. Here and there are small patches of dark conifer woods. A paved trail leads to your left towards one such patch.

The right side of the panels is filled with an aerial view of the area showing a pockmarked landscape, some of the indentations with trees or ponds in their bottom. Text reads, "Potholes. Curious depressions known as "Potholes,' dimple the glacial outwash plain here. Some 15,000 years ago, sediment carried by glacial meltwater buried huge blocks of ice that calved off retreating glaciers. As the ice melted, the ground sank leaving depressions behind known locally as â€˜potholes,' but known more commonly as â€˜kettles.'

"Kettles are bowl-shaped and range in size from 15 feet to Â¼ mile in diameter. These depressions begin as steep-sided features but wind and water smooth the edges and deposit sediment in the bottom.

"Trees take root in some kettles creating forest islands, while water pools in other kettles forming tiny wetland communities. On the semi-arid outwash plain, these islands provide food and shelter for a variety of wildlife.

"Kettles are fragile, isolated ecosystems under constant stress from human impacts. Essentially fossil icebergs, the Potholes here relate to kettles found in other glaciated regions of North America providing insight into our changing environment.

"A short Â¼-mile trail leads around the forested Pothole nearby."

title: Preserving a Legacy
listingDescription:
The Burt family lived in this cabin for many summers on the ranch. Their son, Nathaniel, was even born on the kitchen table one winter. Several other people and families cared for the Bar BC over the decades, including Horace Carncross, Struthers Burt's original partner; Irving Corse and his family, who took the ranch over from the Burts; Peggy Conderman of the neighboring 4 Lazy F Ranch; and Margaretta Sharpless, Irving Corse's widow.
