The Western Center for Historic Preservation and Grand Teton National Park, in partnership with the Grand Teton National Park Foundation, are working on a multi-year project to stabilize and preserve this cabin and other buildings here, so that visitors can continue to enjoy them and learn about the Bar BC.

Though the families who lived here and the guests who came to stay are gone, their legacy remains in these buildings, the beginnings of tourism in Jackson Hole, and the formation of Grand Teton National Park. Visitors to the valley today experience the same wonder and joy at the high peaks, the cool swimming holes, and the novelty of Western life. Though the dudes and wranglers have left, and these cabins are now empty, you can still explore the Bar BC and imagine the experiences they had here.

images.altText: A large log cabin decorated with elk antlers on the eaves stands among tall pine trees, with snow-capped peaks in the distance.
images.caption: The main cabin as it looked in its heyday (photo courtesy of the Burt Family).

Excerpt from "Diary of a Dude Wrangler": "I have a thousand and one golden memories as well as a thousand and one tales. Memories of faces and voices and laughter, of rides and camps and loveliness seen in company. Of crisp mornings when snow-clad peaks soared against blue skies with the still whiteness of gigantic pelicans, of nights when the moon, coming up behind the sleeping ranges to the east, picked out for a moment a ragged pine, and made isolation suddenly another companion, and flooded the sage-brush with light so that you saw ambergris floating in a sea of silver. For a week or two in the late autumn when everyone is gone, a dude-ranch is a lovely place-haunted."

title: Price of the Ferry
listingDescription: Menor charged 50c for a wagon and team and 25c for a rider and horse. Pedestrians rode free if a wagon was crossing. When the water was too low for the ferry, Menor suspended a platform from the cable and three to four passengers could ride a primitive cablecar across the river. In later years, Menor and his neighbors built a bridge for winter use, dismantling it each spring.Menor sold out to Maude Noble in 1918. She doubled the fares, hoping to earn a living from the growing

images.altText: A landscape photo with the snake river in the foreground, ferry boat in the river on the opposite bank, and the whitewashed buildings of Menors Ferry with the Teton Range towering above.

bodyText:
Menor charged 50c for a wagon and team and 25c for a rider and horse. Pedestrians rode free if a wagon was crossing. When the water was too low for the ferry, Menor suspended a platform from the cable and three to four passengers could ride a primitive cablecar across the river. In later years, Menor and his neighbors built a bridge for winter use, dismantling it each spring.

Menor sold out to Maude Noble in 1918. She doubled the fares, hoping to earn a living from the growing number of tourists in the valley. Noble charged $1 for automobiles with local license plates, or $2 for out-of-state plates. In 1927, a steel truss bridge was built just south of the ferry, making it obsolete. Maude Noble sold the property to the Snake River Land Company in 1929.
audioDescription: Audio Tour Site

title: Root Cellar
listingDescription: Bill Menors Root Cellar.

images.altText: Front of a white painted log building with a door that is 12 feet square with a low pitched roof. A small exhibit panel is to the right of the door.
images.caption: Root Cellar

bodyText: Bill Menors Root Cellar.

title: Saddle Up
listingDescription: Trail rides were a popular pastime on the ranch, much as they still are in the park today. The tack room was a hub of activity. Wranglers would catch the horses each morning on their pasture and bring them down to the ranch. When guests were ready to go on a trail ride, the wranglers saddled up the horses and brought them out. Dudes often rode the same horse for years, developing a strong attachment. Look for the horses' names written on the wall, above where their saddles would have hung.

images.altText: A gentleman sits on horseback in front of the saddle room at the Bar BC.
images.caption: A Bar BC guest poses on horseback in front of the tack room, in the late 1920s. (Photo courtesy of the Jackson Hole Historical Society and Museum, 2005.0121.024)

bodyText: Trail rides were a popular pastime on the ranch, much as they still are in the park today. The tack room was a hub of activity. Wranglers would catch the horses each morning on their pasture and bring them down to the ranch. When guests were ready to go on a trail ride, the wranglers saddled up the horses and brought them out. Dudes often rode the same horse for years, developing a strong attachment. Look for the horses' names written on the wall, above where their saddles would have hung.
audioDescription:
Host: Trail rides were a popular pastime on the ranch, much as they still are in the park today. The tack room was a hub of activity. Wranglers would catch the horses each morning on their pasture and bring them down to the ranch. When guests were ready to go on a trail ride, the wranglers saddled up the horses and brought them out. Dudes often rode the same horse for years, developing a strong attachment. Look for the horses' names written on the wall, above where their saddles would have hung.

Excerpt from "Diary of a Dude Wrangler": "Dude-horses are in a class by themselves. They are not easy to find. They must have a combination of qualities rare in any single animal, and certainly non-existent in the human animal. They must be young and fast, yet gentle and easy-gaited, and infinitely wise. I have seen the ignorant perform about them, and on them, feats that leave the cowpuncher gasping. Twice, I have seen people get on backward! Yes-they put the right foot in the left stirrup and with the utmost abandon, swung the left leg over the horse's head and landed facing the horse's tail, an exploit difficult for even the trained rider."

title: Sargents Bay Picnic Area
listingDescription: Sargents Bay picnic area is one of several of small picnic areas in the northern part of the park. This minimal facility includes a few picnic tables and is ABA accessible.

images.altText: Brown wooden sign for Sargents Bay Picnic Area along north highway.
images.caption: Sargents Bay Picnic Area

bodyText:
Sargents Bay picnic area is one of several of small picnic areas in the northern part of the park. This minimal facility includes a few picnic tables and is ABA accessible.

Name Origin

John D. Sargent and Robert Ray Hamilton built a guest lodge, the Merymere, in the 1880s above Leeks marina. Both were black sheep descended from famous families (John Singer Sargent and Alexander Hamilton). Sargent was suspected of murdering his partner leading to the name of Signal Mountain.

title: Sawmill Ponds Overlook
listingDescription: In 1923, Al Young relocated his sawmill to the marshy area near Moose that today we call Sawmill Ponds. He produced lumber for buildings in the area. Today these wetlands are home to moose and many other species such as waterfowl and beaver. Dawn and dusk are the best time to look for wildlife, but you may catch a glimpse during the heat of the day.

images.altText: Three visitors at the Sawmill Ponds Overlook reading the wayside. The pond is below and spruce trees around the edge.
images.caption: Visitors at Sawmill Ponds Overlook

bodyText:
In 1923, Al Young relocated his sawmill to the marshy area near Moose that today we call Sawmill Ponds. He produced lumber for buildings in the area. Today these wetlands are home to moose and many other species such as waterfowl and beaver. Dawn and dusk are the best time to look for wildlife, but you may catch a glimpse during the heat of the day.

Name Origin

Al Young operated a sawmill near the spring-fed beaver pond until establishment of the park in 1929.
audioDescription:
This dirt-and-gravel turnout overlooks a long narrow pond stretching from left to right at the bottom of a steep, 60 foot-bank. At the far side, dark evergreen trees line the marshy land surrounding the pond. The parking lot is edged with rough logs, which do not form a solid barrier.

A wayside sign at the edge of the parking lot is titled, "Moose Habitat." It has a photograph of a bull moose, standing in the sunshine, it's head with large antlers, drooping slightly, eyes half-closed. Text reads, "Moose thrive in wetlands abundant with willow, marsh grasses, and aquatic plants. Solitary by nature, some moose stay in this habitat year-round. Others migrate seasonally, traveling into mountain canyons to feed on summer vegetation and return to the valley as winter approaches.

"Moose are not the only inhabitants that live here, however. This habitat provides a living place for other animals that directly benefit from moose occupying this space. The antlers on a bull moose reach full size in late summer, but after the autumn rut, they shed their antlers in early winter. Rodents and other animals gnaw on the fallen antlers providing a valuable source of calcium critical to their survival.

"The largest member of the deer family, moose may weigh more than 1,000 pounds and stand seven feet tall. Moose may appear docile, but they are unpredictable and powerful. Rutting bulls may charge people and cows fiercely protect their calves."

title: Schwabacher Landing
listingDescription: From the parking lot, hike north along a small channel of the Snake River about 350 yards (320 m) to a large beaver dam. Beaver constantly work to enlarge and reinforce their dams. They are most active around dawn and dusk. When the wind is calm, the pond reflects the central Teton Range framed by spruce and cottonwood trees. At one time, enough water flowed through this channel for boats to launch at Schwabachers Landing. Today, the river has shifted course-preventing boats

images.altText: Reflection view at Schwabachers Landing with conifers surrounding quiet water and the central Teton Range in the background.
images.caption: Reflection at Schwabacher Landing

bodyText:
From the parking lot, hike north along a small channel of the Snake River about 350 yards (320 m) to a large beaver dam. Beaver constantly work to enlarge and reinforce their dams. They are most active around dawn and dusk. When the wind is calm, the pond reflects the central Teton Range framed by spruce and cottonwood trees. At one time, enough water flowed through this channel for boats to launch at Schwabachers Landing. Today, the river has shifted course-preventing boats from accessing the river here.

This area is popular for wildlife viewing, scenic photos and weddings. To plan a wedding in the park, please visit our website.
audioDescription: The gravel parking area here provides access to a slow moving branch of the Snake River. To the east, the land rises in smooth terraces up to the highway. On the east side of the parking area is a single, unisex vault toilet with the entrance to the left. From the west side of the parking lot, the wide dirt and gravel path leads down a gentle slope to the water's edge. To the left a beaver dam crosses the river. To the right, a trail heads north along the river's edge. The wide trail is lined on either side with logs. Across the river are spectacular views of the central peaks of the Tetons, the sharp points of the Cathedral Group. The long, bumpy ridge of Rockchuck Peak lies more to the right, and still further is the rounded summit of Mount Moran.

title: Signal Mountain
listingDescription:
On a clear day, the sweeping view from the summit of Signal Mountain captures five mountain ranges surrounding the Jackson Hole valley. The Teton Range rises to the west, the Snake River Range to the southwest, the Gros Ventre Range to the southeast, the Absarokas to the east and Yellowstone Plateau to the north.

In early summer wildflowers add splashes of yellow, pink and lavender to the silvery gray-green of the sagebrush. The Snake River winds it way south from Jackson Lake cutting a silver swath across the valley. Either hike or drive to this summit that rises about 900 feet above the valley--the highest road in the park.

images.altText: Visitors on the summit of Signal Mountain looking toward Teton Range.
images.caption: Signal Mountain Summit

bodyText:
On a clear day, the sweeping view from the summit of Signal Mountain captures five mountain ranges surrounding the Jackson Hole valley. The Teton Range rises to the west, the Snake River Range to the southwest, the Gros Ventre Range to the southeast, the Absarokas to the east and Yellowstone Plateau to the north.

In early summer wildflowers add splashes of yellow, pink and lavender to the silvery gray-green of the sagebrush. The Snake River winds it way south from Jackson Lake cutting a silver swath across the valley. Either hike or drive to this summit that rises about 900 feet above the valley--the highest road in the park.

Name Origin

In 1891, Robert Ray Hamilton went missing while hunting in Jackson Hole. Searchers agreed to light a signal fire on the summit of this mountain when he was found. Seven days later, Hamilton's drowned body was found in the Snake River two miles below Jackson Lake Dam. His partner, John D. Sargent, was a suspect in Hamilton's demise.
audioDescription:
The viewing area at the summit of Signal Mountain is reached by a broad paved pathway that curves up from the southern edge of the parking area. Backed by woods to the west, Grand Teton is visible to the south, which is back in the direction of the access path, with the rest of the Teton Range stretching further to the south. To the east the ground falls away steeply with views over the wide valley to the distant mountain ranges surrounding it. From the north end of the viewing area opposite the path, you can see the ridge of Signal Mountain with the access road winding up it.

There is a small, unisex vault toilet at the southern edge of the parking area.

title: Signal Mountain General Store
listingDescription:
The General Store offers supplies and snacks for camping and outdoor activities. Pick up fishing supplies and bait, camping equipment and toiletries in addition to natural food choices, snacks, drinks and ice.

Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.

images.altText: Signal Mountain General Store and Gas Station with car parked in front and ice machine to the right.
images.caption: Signal Mountain General Store

bodyText:
The General Store offers supplies and snacks for camping and outdoor activities. Pick up fishing supplies and bait, camping equipment and toiletries in addition to natural food choices, snacks, drinks and ice.

Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.
audioDescription: As you face the water, the General Store is located at the left end of the parking lot. There are three gas pumps in front of the store. To the left of the door is an antique (non-functional gas pump). To the right of the door is a bench, several trash bins and an ice freezer. A wood plank sidewalk leads down the left side of the building to two unisex restrooms towards the rear.

title: Signal Mountain Launch
listingDescription:
Location: Three miles south of Jackson Lake Junction is the Signal Mountain Lodge area. This visitor service area includes a campground, lodge, restaurants, convenience store, gas station, gift shops, marina and boat launch. Partly sheltered to the west by Donoho Point, the marina offers stunning views of Mount Moran across the lake.

Notes: Signal Mountain is a full service marina and experiences minimal impacts by low-water years on Jackson Lake. The boat launch is east of the main lodge area.

Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.

images.altText: White truck with trailer backing a power boat down the Signal Mountain boat launch into Jackson Lake.
images.caption: Launching at Signal Mountain

bodyText:
Location: Three miles south of Jackson Lake Junction is the Signal Mountain Lodge area. This visitor service area includes a campground, lodge, restaurants, convenience store, gas station, gift shops, marina and boat launch. Partly sheltered to the west by Donoho Point, the marina offers stunning views of Mount Moran across the lake.

Notes: Signal Mountain is a full service marina and experiences minimal impacts by low-water years on Jackson Lake. The boat launch is east of the main lodge area.

Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.
audioDescription: The boat launch here is a wide paved ramp that slopes gently down in to the lake. Looking out over the lake here provides a striking view of the broad flat-topped peak of Mount Moran with a glacier down its front side, flanked by smaller mountain peaks on either side.

title: Signal Mountain Laundry & Showers
listingDescription:
Stop by Signal Mountain for coin operated showers and laundry facilities open to all visitors. The showers feature private shower rooms. These facilities recently opened improving accommodations in the park!
Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.

images.altText: Brown log building with signs "Public Showers" and "Laundromat". A buck and rail fence surrounds the area.
images.caption: Public Showers & Laundromat

bodyText:
Stop by Signal Mountain for coin operated showers and laundry facilities open to all visitors. The showers feature private shower rooms. These facilities recently opened improving accommodations in the park!
Visit the Signal Mountain website for more information.
audioDescription: The building with the laundry and showers is in the shape of an "L" with the short extension on the right end. It is made of dark-stained logs with a brown metal roof. A sidewalk near the right hand end of the building leads to short set of steps and on to the wooden deck in front. An accessible ramp is located at the far left end of the building. The entrance to the laundry is to the right off the porch. Doors to the individual showers are spaced along the front of the building. At the right end of the building a dirt path leads behind to the Convenience Store and lodge parking lot.

title: Signal Mountain Lodge
listingDescription:
Signal Mountain Lodge offers a variety of overnight accommodations. Located on the shores of Jackson Lake, spend the night in a rustic cabin or a lakefront suite. All rooms are grouped 3 or 4 units per building. Enjoy the park right out your front door.

Visit the Signal Mountain website.

images.altText: Lodging registration building for Signal Mountain Lodge. Tan two-story building with dark brown trim. Sign over parking structure reads "Lodging Registration."
images.caption: Lodging Registration

bodyText:
Signal Mountain Lodge offers a variety of overnight accommodations. Located on the shores of Jackson Lake, spend the night in a rustic cabin or a lakefront suite. All rooms are grouped 3 or 4 units per building. Enjoy the park right out your front door.

Visit the Signal Mountain website.

Name Origin

In 1891, Robert Ray Hamilton went missing while hunting in Jackson Hole. Searchers agreed to light a signal fire on the summit of this mountain when he was found. Seven days later, Hamilton's drowned body was found in the Snake River two miles below Jackson Lake Dam. His partner, John D. Sargent, was a suspect in Hamilton's demise.

Season

Expected to open no earlier than June 5, 2020. Closes early October.
audioDescription:
The entrance to the lodge is under a large roofed extension over the paved driveway. There are two shallow steps up to the large, glass door or from the sidewalk on either side of the door are short cement ramps. The lower part of the building is faced with flat stonework. Above that the board-and-batten siding is painted a light brown with dark brown trim.

Inside the entrance a wide hallway leads past two stairways and an office door to the registration desk on the right. The flooring is polished wood planking with area rugs scattered about. On the left side of the hallway is a set of glass doors and then a water bottle refill station. Just opposite the registration desk is a small sitting nook. Restrooms are down a short hallway leading off the back right corner of the nook.

Past the registration desk, the hallway opens into a large sitting room running along the rear of the building. The outer wall is composed of large picture windows. Towards the left is a glass door leading out onto a small wooden deck at the rear of the building.

title: Signal Mountain Marina
listingDescription:
Location: Three miles south of Jackson Lake Junction is the Signal Mountain Lodge area. This visitor service area includes a campground, lodge, restaurants, convenience store, gas station, gift shops and marina. Partly sheltered to the west by Donoho Point, the marina offers stunning views of Mount Moran across the lake.

Notes: Signal Mountain is a full service marina and experiences minimal impacts during low-water years on Jackson Lake. Rent motorized or non-motorized boats or book a guided fishing tour on Jackson Lake.

Visit the Signal Mountain website.

images.altText: Visitors on porch of Signal Mountain Marina office just above Jackson Lake with sidewalk and buck and rail fence.
images.caption: Signal Mountain Marina Office

bodyText:
Location: Three miles south of Jackson Lake Junction is the Signal Mountain Lodge area. This visitor service area includes a campground, lodge, restaurants, convenience store, gas station, gift shops and marina. Partly sheltered to the west by Donoho Point, the marina offers stunning views of Mount Moran across the lake.

Notes: Signal Mountain is a full service marina and experiences minimal impacts during low-water years on Jackson Lake. Rent motorized or non-motorized boats or book a guided fishing tour on Jackson Lake.

Visit the Signal Mountain website.

Regulations

All boats including paddleboards launched in Grand Teton National Park must have a park permit. Purchase permits at the permits desk in the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center in Moose or the Colter Bay permits office. More information on park boat regulations.

Boat inspections required for all boats entering Wyoming between March 1 and November 30 for Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS). AIS inspection stations near Moose and Moran. Boat owners must buy a decal to support this program. Decals available at Snake River Anglers in Dornans or at the Colter Bay Marina; and other Wyoming Game and Fish outlets. More information on state boat regulations .
audioDescription:
The Marina is a small rectangular building at the edge of the lake. Its wood siding is stained a dark brown and it has a brown metal roof. As you move down the sidewalk from the parking lot, the entrance is to your right, under a roofed porch area. There is a bench along the wall to the right of the door.

The lakeshore here is gently sloped and covered with small pebbles, providing easy access to the water. One short boat dock extends into the water next to the marina office. A longer one lies to your left as you come down the sidewalk.

A low island lies out the water in front of you with mountain peaks rising beyond. The tall, slightly rounded peak of Mount Moran lies to your left.

title: Signal Mountain Restaurants & Gift Shops
listingDescription: Enjoy dining or shopping at the Signal Mountain Lodge. The Trapper Grill is open all day serving breakfast, specialty sandwiches, burgers and nachos. The Peaks Restaurant offers western bistro fare for dinner. Or step in Deadman's Bar for a drink and a snack. Learn more about dining options. The Needles Gift Store specializes in clothing, accessories, Native American jewelry and gifts. The Timbers Gift Store offers a great selection of apparel and hiking souvenirs. Learn more

images.altText: Front of Signal Mountain Lodge building that houses gift shops and restaurants. Stone facade in center with tan building and dark brown trim.
images.caption: Signal Mountain Lodge Restaurants

bodyText:
Enjoy dining or shopping at the Signal Mountain Lodge. The Trapper Grill is open all day serving breakfast, specialty sandwiches, burgers and nachos. Or step in Deadman's Bar for a drink and a snack.
Learn more about dining options.

The Needles Gift Store specializes in clothing, accessories, Native American jewelry and gifts. 

Learn more about shopping.
audioDescription:
This is a long building along the side of the parking lot facing the water. Its vertical siding is painted light brown with dark brown trim. Its metal roof is also painted dark brown and extends to a chalet-style peak in the center of the front of the building where a column faced with flat stonework holds a sign reading "Signal Mountain Lodge." The entrance is through double glass doors about 15 feet to the left of the stonework.

There are two gift shops inside the building. On your left as you enter is the main gift shop. On the right is a smaller shop with clothing. The stone-tiled first hallway extends to the rear of the building, then turns to the left where the restrooms are located. A second hallway turns to the right past the clothing shop. The hallway then turns back to the left to reach the restaurants and bar.

title: Signal Mountain Trailhead
listingDescription:
Location: Access the Signal Mountain trail through the Signal Mountain campground or drive up the Signal Mountain Summit Road about one mile. Park near the pond and backtrack down the road to cut around the pond to the south.

Notes: This trail is lightly traveled. If you park near the Signal Mountain Lodge or Campground, you will have access to restrooms, water and a store. If you drive up the Signal Mountain Road to begin your hike, there are no facilities. Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray. This trail does not access backcountry camping areas.

images.altText: Visitors hiking near summit of Signal Mountain with sagebrush and wildflowers. The Teton Range is in the background.
images.caption: Hikers Near Summit

bodyText:
Location: Access the Signal Mountain trail through the Signal Mountain campground or drive up the Signal Mountain Summit Road about one mile. Park near the pond and backtrack down the road to cut around the pond to the south.

Notes: This trail is lightly traveled. If you park near the Signal Mountain Lodge or Campground, you will have access to restrooms, water and a store. If you drive up the Signal Mountain Road to begin your hike, there are no facilities. Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray. This trail does not access backcountry camping areas.

Destination

While most visitors drive to the summit, a moderate hiking trail will allow you to avoid the crowds!

6.8 miles RT loop, 4 hours, 850 ft total climbing, Moderate.
Traverse forests to viewpoint. Park at Signal Mountain Lodge and walk on park road to trail or cut through the campground to reach the trailhead.

Name Origin

In 1891, Robert Ray Hamilton went missing while hunting in Jackson Hole. Searchers agreed to light a signal fire on the summit of this mountain when he was found. Seven days later, Hamilton's drowned body was found in the Snake River two miles below Jackson Lake Dam. His partner, John D. Sargent, was a suspect in Hamilton's demise.

title: Sleeping Indian Turnout
listingDescription: The Sleeping Indian is a nickname for Sheep Mountain. Facing east, the long ridge climbs south from the Gros Ventre River rising above tree line as if a person is lying down. Further south, the ridge rises more steeply as a series of limestone cliffs forming the person's crossed arms. A notch forms the neck and chin while the face slopes to the south. Steep limestone cliffs wrap around the face forming the Indian's headdress. Some visualize the Indian quite easily; some do not.

images.altText: Closeup of Sleeping Indian limestone cliffs create the headdress.
images.caption: Closeup Sleeping Indian

bodyText:
The Sleeping Indian is a nickname for Sheep Mountain. Facing east, the long ridge climbs south from the Gros Ventre River rising above tree line as if a person is lying down. Further south, the ridge rises more steeply as a series of limestone cliffs forming the person's crossed arms. A notch forms the neck and chin while the face slopes to the south. Steep limestone cliffs wrap around the face forming the Indian's headdress. Some visualize the Indian quite easily; some do not.

Name Origin

The official name of this summer is Sheep Mountain for the bighorn sheep that graze on its slope. The unofficial name is "Sleeping Indian" because it resembles an Indian chief wearing a feather headdress stretched out on his back. Limestone cliffs form the headdress. This summit is part of the Gros Ventre Range extending south and east from Jackson Hole.

History

In 1925, a large landslide occurred on the north end of Sheep Mountain, damming the Gros Ventre River and forming Lower Slide Lake. In 1927, the natural dam partially failed and a torrent of water flooded across the valley. Six people were killed in Kelly and water was 3 feet deep in Wilson at the base of Teton Pass.
audioDescription: This turnout on the east side of Highway 89 does not have a wayside sign, but offers a clear view of the mountains to the east. One striking formation has been likened to an American Indian lying on his back, arms folded over his chest. The rocky cliffs that form the right end of the mountain look like a feathered headdress surrounding a head. The ridgeline continues to the left up to a small peak, which serves as a nose. Continuing to the left, there is a gap for the chin and neck before rising to a rounded peak where the folded arms would be. The ridge then continues smoothly to the left, representing the rest of the body, until it disappears below tree line.

title: Smokehouse
listingDescription: Bill Menors Smokehouse.

images.altText: Elevations and plan of the smokehouse. Drawing shows all four sides and top down view of smokehouse.
images.caption: Historic American Buildings Survey Drawing

bodyText: Bill Menors Smokehouse.

title: Snake River Overlook
listingDescription: Ansel Adams photographed this iconic view of the Teton Range and Snake River from roughly this vantage point. The sweep of the Snake River below the sagebrush flats and the high peaks of the Teton Range towering above enthrall all who visit. Today visitors try to capture this image forgetting that trees have grown and the exact location is not known. Below this point, rafters access the Snake River at Deadmans Bar coming downstream from Pacific Creek or continuing on to Moose.

images.altText: Ansel Adams iconic image of the Snake River in the foreground and the central Teton Range in the background.
images.caption: Ansel Adams: Tetons and the Snake River

bodyText:
Ansel Adams photographed this iconic view of the Teton Range and Snake River from roughly this vantage point. The sweep of the Snake River below the sagebrush flats and the high peaks of the Teton Range towering above enthrall all who visit. Today visitors try to capture this image forgetting that trees have grown and the exact location is not known. Below this point, rafters access the Snake River at Deadmans Bar coming downstream from Pacific Creek or continuing on to Moose.

Name Origin

The headwaters for the Snake River are in the Teton Wilderness just outside of Yellowstone National Park. After flowing into Yellowstone briefly, the river cuts through Grand Teton National Park, across Idaho and flows into the Columbia River in Washington.

Previous names include the Lewis River (after Lewis & Clark), La Maudite Riviere Enragee (The Accursed Mad River by French fur trappers), the Mad River, Sho-sho-ne-pah (or Shoshone Indians) that lead to the final name Snake River.
audioDescription:
This overlook provides stunning views of the Snake River and the mountain range beyond from the top of a high terrace of land. From the parking lot, a maze of concrete aggregate paths leads to a broad walkway along a 3-foot high stone wall at the edge of the steep bluff. Down below the river comes from the right, makes a U-bend, then curves back to the left. Beyond the jagged peaks of the Tetons rise.

There are three wayside signs along the stone wall. The one at the far right is titled "Tetons Inspiring Creativity." The right side of the sign shows a painting by Thomas Moran of the Teton range from the west. In the foreground a river runs through a boulder-filled channel. Behind it is a snow-covered mountain peak. In the lower left of the panel is an historic photograph of Moran sitting on a boulder beside a stream cascading down the steep hillside. He has a long beard and wears a hat and high boots.

The main text on the panel reads, "Thomas Moran found the Tetons awe-inspiring even though he, unlike you, was facing the range's western slope. Moran created a series of watercolor field sketches in 1879 and later used them with William H. Jackson's photographs to compose large idealized oil paintings. His images conveyed the vastness and beauty of the West to easterners and helped promote the establishment of national parks. His iconic artwork hangs today in major museums and the U.S. Capitol. Moran first visited this region in 1871 with Ferdinand V. Hayden's Yellowstone geological survey expedition."

Along the bottom of the panel is a quote from Moran: "The Tetons ... loomed up grandly against the sky. From this point it is perhaps the finest pictorial range in the United States or ever."

The middle wayside along the wall is titled "Capturing Nature in a Box." The right side of the panel shows a famous black and white photograph of the Snake River made by Ansel Adams. The view in the photograph is very close to the view from this overlook, with the river winding below and Grand Teton peak dominating the mountain range behind.

At the bottom left of the panel is an historic photograph of Adams in Yosemite Valley in 1942. He stands on a wooden platform built on top of a Pontiac station wagon with his large-format, bellows camera in front of him.

The main text reads, "Ansel Adams stood here in 1942 and took this photograph of the vast unspoiled beauty of the Snake River and jagged Teton Range. The National Park Service hired Adams in 1941 to capture nature as exemplified by national parks. At the time local ranchers were battling a proposal to include the Jackson Hole valley in Grand Teton National Park. Adams's photographs helped promote and protect western U.S. landscapes."

Along the bottom of the panel is a quote from Adams: "The grand lift of the Tetons is ... a primal gesture of the Earth beneath a greater sky."

The leftmost wayside is titled "Meandering Snake." It is filled with a color photograph of a sharp U-bend in the river, the water very smooth, reflecting trees and sky. Text reads, "The Snake River twists and turns as it flows over 1,000 miles from Yellowstone National Park through Grand Teton National Park and ultimately to the Pacific Ocean. From Jackson Hole the Snake turns west into Idaho and eventually joins the Columbia River, which flows into the Pacific. This designated Wild and Scenic River attracts river otters, bald eagles, osprey, moose-and human anglers and rafters.

A caption tells us the Snake River was named for a serpentine gesture the Shoshone Indians use to describe themselves.

An inset in the upper right of the panel shows a large rubber raft filled with people floating on the river. The caption reads, "Float the Snake River for excellent views of the Tetons and wildlife."

To the right of that a smaller photo shows a bald eagle perched on a tree branch. The caption reads, "Look for bald eagles soaring over the Snake River as they prey on fish and waterfowl. Since the 1972 ban on DDT pesticide, the once-endangered bald eagle has recovered in most of the nation."

title: South Boundary Turnout
listingDescription:
This viewpoint offers sweeping views of the Teton Range from a knob in Jackson Hole valley. Stop here to capture a classic image of the wooden park welcome sign and the vista. The National Elk Refuge and the town of Jackson lie to the south. Blacktail Butte is just north. The Gros Ventre Range stretches to the southeast and the Teton Range rises to the west.

Notice the abrupt change from the sagebrush flats of the valley floor to the mountains-no foothills block your view. The sagebrush flats reflect the leveling of ice-age glaciers that flowed across the valley numerous times. Movement on the Teton fault lifted the mountain block skyward while the valley floor hinged down resulting in a lack of foothills.

images.altText: Group of visitors at the South Boundary Turnout with the sagebrush flats and Teton Range beyone
images.caption: South Boundary Turnout

bodyText:
This viewpoint offers sweeping views of the Teton Range from a knob in Jackson Hole valley. Stop here to capture a classic image of the wooden park welcome sign and the vista. The National Elk Refuge and the town of Jackson lie to the south. Blacktail Butte is just north. The Gros Ventre Range stretches to the southeast and the Teton Range rises to the west.

Notice the abrupt change from the sagebrush flats of the valley floor to the mountains-no foothills block your view. The sagebrush flats reflect the leveling of ice-age glaciers that flowed across the valley numerous times. Movement on the Teton fault lifted the mountain block skyward while the valley floor hinged down resulting in a lack of foothills.
audioDescription:
This turnout is on the southern boundary of Grand Teton National Park. There are paved sidewalk areas on either side of the parking lot. On either side are broad, flat sagebrush covered meadows. The Teton Range rises to the left, or west, and lower mountain ranges lie to the right in the east. Also towards the east is the high, wire and wood post fence which borders the National Elk Refuge.

On the west side of the turnout is a large wooden sign for Grand Teton National Park with the mountains outlined in white at the top. It hangs from a large wooden post structure in a base built of medium-sized stones.

On the east side of the turnout are three wayside signs, two smaller ones at either end and a larger, two-panel sign hanging in a wooden post structure in the middle.

The wayside on the far left is titled "The Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem." On the right side of the panel is a map of the region around the point where the states of Wyoming, Montana and Idaho meet. Yellowstone National Park is in the northwest corner of Wyoming with the smaller Grand Teton National Park just south of it. A pale green area indicating the extent of the ecosystem extends well up past Yellowstone in to Montana, west into Idaho and further east and south into Wyoming. The text reads, "You are standing within the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem, the largest nearly intact natural area remaining in the contiguous United States. Grand Teton and Yellowstone national parks, seven national forests and two national wildlife refuges comprise most of its acreage, but federal, state, and private lands also provide essential buggers to this ecosystem and its free-roaming wildlife.

"Bison, elk, bears, and eagles once thrived nationwide. Now, these and many other species survive in this island of hope. Preservation of this ecosystem and the wildlife it supports will mean much to future generations."

At the top of the panel are the outline shapes of native animals and plants, such as bison, eagles, elk and bear. At the bottom is a sketch showing the different habitats, ranging from alpine on the tops of the mountains, down through spruce and fir forest, then pine forest, flat sagebrush plain, and low wetlands.

The middle wayside has two panels. The left hand panel shows a photo of mountain peaks at the top. Text reads, "Explore Teton Country. Discover the magnificent landscape and wild communities of Grand Teton National Park. Here the Teton Range rises abruptly from the high mountain valley known as Jackson Hole. From bare alpine rocks to lush meadows and floodplains, the national park is home to bald eagles, grizzly bears, river otters, and bison."

Underneath the photo is a quote: "Today, come to this national park with an open mind, open eyes, and an open heart ... walk the trails ... canoe ... you may see a moose or two ... a great blue heron, a pair of trumpeter swans ... These quiet adventures will remain with you always.-Margaret E. "Mardy" Murie"

A band of photos across the middle of the panel show, from left to right, several canoes being paddled on smooth water with reflections of autumn trees, a group of schoolchildren in a meadow with a park ranger, a mother elk with her calf and a bright blue tent near a lake. Below these an inset photo shows a large moose crossing a road and at the bottom two hikers in a meadow with the mountain range in the distance.

Additional text blocks read, "Plan Your Visit. Pick up a map and newspaper at any entrance station or visitor center to help plan your trip. Stop at visitor centers for orientation information, ranger-led activities, and interpretive exhibits.

"Be Extra Careful. Drive carefully, obey speed limits, and watch for wildlife on roads. Drivers hit and kill more than 100 large animals on park roads each year. Animals are wild. Do not feed or approach them. Stay more than 100 yards away from all large animals.

"Be "Bear Aware." Black and grizzly bears can be anywhere in the park. Protect your food and toiletries from bears, even toothpaste and sunscreen. It all smells to a bear. Please be careful. Follow food storage regulations. Do not leave food unattended. Keep pets on a leash six feet long or less. Pets are not allowed on unpaved trails, the multi-use pathway or in the visitor centers."

The panel on the right is titled "Mapping Your Teton Adventure." It shows a map of Grand Teton National Park and the JDR Memorial Parkway north of the park. Your current location at the southern boundary is marked with a red flag. At the top right is a photo of a bald eagle in flight. At the bottom right is a photo of an elk.

The far right wayside is titled "Elk Migration." Text reads, "The National Elk Refuge. In the high country, deep November snows cause elk to migrate to their winter range on the National Elk Refuge. In strings of 200 or more, thousands of elk arrive, some after traveling more than 65 miles from southern Yellowstone National Park and surround national forests.

Settlement and development eliminated nearly three-fourths of the elk's natural winter range. The 23,000-acre National Elk Refuge was established in 1912 to protect the remaining winter habitat. Throughout the year, several different national and state agencies manage the herd and its habitat."

At the top right of the panel is a drawing of a line of elk moving left to right with mountains in the background. In the lower right hand corner is a map showing the paths of the migration in green. The map is oriented with south at the top where the National Elk Refuge is marked. Many paths from the northeast, north, and northwest converge into a broad path leading to the refuge.

At the bottom left of the panel is a photograph of a mother elk nursing a tiny calf. The caption reads, "The elk (properly called wapiti) leave the Refuge in April when winter snows begin to melt. Calves are born in late May and June as the elk migrate to their summer ranges."

Next to that another photograph shows a large group of elk in a snowy landscape, some standing, some lying down. The caption reads, "The winter herd on the National Elk Refuge exceeds 7,500 animals. About one-half of these elk summer in Grand Teton National Park. The elk are not confined; the Refuge fence protects them from the road."

title: Spalding Bay Campsites
listingDescription:
Location : The Spalding Bay road turns north off the Teton Park Road between the Mountain View and Mount Moran turnouts. The junction is not signed. Follow the dirt road about 2.25 miles to the shore of Jackson Lake. The last part of the road may be rough. Please use caution.

Description : The Spalding Bay campsites face east across the bay and are partly sheltered from the prevailing southwest winds. Enjoy the vista across Jackson Lake toward Donaho Point, and waves lapping on the lakeshore. Conifer trees and grass cover the area.

People who want to camp here need to get a backcountry permit in advance. Backcountry permits are available at three permits offices: Moose and Colter Bay visitor centers and the Jenny Lake Ranger Station. Submit reservations between early January and mid-May, or stop by a permit office to see if a site is available (fee charged).

images.altText: Spalding Bay area with vehicles parked and Jackson Lake beyond
images.caption: Spalding Bay

bodyText:
Location : The Spalding Bay road turns north off the Teton Park Road between the Mountain View and Mount Moran turnouts. The junction is not signed. Follow the dirt road about 2.25 miles to the shore of Jackson Lake. The last part of the road may be rough. Please use caution.

Description : The Spalding Bay campsites face east across the bay and are partly sheltered from the prevailing southwest winds. Enjoy the vista across Jackson Lake toward Donaho Point, and waves lapping on the lakeshore. Conifer trees and grass cover the area.

People who want to camp here need to get a backcountry permit in advance. Backcountry permits are available at three permits offices: Moose and Colter Bay visitor centers and the Jenny Lake Ranger Station. Submit reservations between early January and mid-May, or stop by a permit office to see if a site is available (fee charged).

Facilities

These two campsites are classified as backcountry sites, but they have several improvements. Picnic tables, bear boxes, tent pads, fire grates and a vault toilet make this location a front country/backcountry site! But, there is no running water.

A backcountry permit is required for camping. Please visit our website for more information.

Name Origin

Bishop Franklin S. Spalding was part of the team who documented the first ascent of the Grand Teton in 1898 along with William O. Owen, John Shive and Frank Petersen. Spalding was the climber who figured out the key move. Owen attempted the climb several times before starting in 1891.

title: Spalding Bay Launch
listingDescription: Location: Turn north from the Teton Park Road about 1.3 miles north of North Jenny Lake Junction or 4.5 miles south of the Signal Mountain Summit Road. The turnoff to Spalding Bay is not marked. The dirt road continues about two miles to Jackson Lake. The bay is sheltered from the prevailing southwesterly afternoon winds and provides views across the lake toward the north and east. The site has parking, picnic tables, vault toilets and bear boxes. Notes: The dirt road into

images.altText: Gravel boat launch at Spalding Bay with small brown wooden sign. Jackson Lake beyond with eastern shore in the distance.
images.caption: Spalding Bay Boat Launch

bodyText:
Location: Turn north from the Teton Park Road about 1.3 miles north of North Jenny Lake Junction or 4.5 miles south of the Signal Mountain Summit Road. The turnoff to Spalding Bay is not marked. The dirt road continues about two miles to Jackson Lake. The bay is sheltered from the prevailing southwesterly afternoon winds and provides views across the lake toward the north and east. The site has parking, picnic tables, vault toilets and bear boxes.

Notes: The dirt road into Spalding Bay can be rough in places. Please use discretion when driving down this road. There is no water at this location. There is very limited parking-about four standard spaces and four large trailer spaces. Call Dispatch 307-739-3301 one day in advance to reserve a large-trailer parking space. Reservations are not required for standard parking spaces.

Spalding Bay is also home to two backcountry campsites accessible by vehicle. Camping requires a backcountry permit available at Colter Bay permits office, Jenny Lake Ranger Station or the permits desk at the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center.

Regulations

All boats including paddleboards launched in Grand Teton National Park must have a park permit. Purchase permits at the permits desk in the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center in Moose or the Colter Bay permits office. More information on park boat regulations .

Boat inspections required for all boats entering Wyoming between March 1 and November 30 for Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS). AIS inspection stations near Moose and Moran. Boat owners must buy a decal to support this program. More information on state boat regulations .

Name Origin

Bishop Franklin S. Spalding was part of the team who documented the first ascent of the Grand Teton in 1898 along with William O. Owen, John Shive and Frank Petersen. Spalding was the climber who figured out the key move. Owen attempted the climb several times before starting in 1891.

title: Stephen Leek Homestead
listingDescription: All that remains of Stephen Leek's 1927 homestead cabin is the stone chimney. Originally a hunting and fishing guide, Leek rose to fame photographing starving elk in Jackson Hole during the harsh winters of the early 1900s. His conservation efforts lead to the establishment of the National Elk Refuge in 1912. Today, thousands of elk congregate on the refuge north of Jackson during winter seeking forage on their native wintering grounds. During summer, look for elk grazing in meadows along the Teton Park Road early in the morning or late in the evening. The heat of the day drives the elk into the cool shade of the adjacent lodgepole pine forest.

images.altText: Historic wayside about Stephen Leek with the homestead chimney behind
images.caption: Stephen Leek's Camera Conservation

bodyText:
All that remains of Stephen Leek's 1927 homestead cabin is the stone chimney. Originally a hunting and fishing guide, Leek rose to fame photographing starving elk in Jackson Hole during the harsh winters of the early 1900s. His conservation efforts lead to the establishment of the National Elk Refuge in 1912. Today, thousands of elk congregate on the refuge north of Jackson during winter seeking forage on their native wintering grounds. During summer, look for elk grazing in meadows along the Teton Park Road early in the morning or late in the evening. The heat of the day drives the elk into the cool shade of the adjacent lodgepole pine forest.

Name Origin

Stephen Leek was a cattle rancher, conservationist and entrepreneur. He settled in the southern part of the Jackson Hole valley in the 1880s. Before 1900, he established Leek's "clubhouse" on the north end of Leigh Lake and then Leek's Camp on the east shore of Jackson Lake as hunting and fishing camps. Later, Leek took photographs of starving and dying elk during the winter of 1908-09. He used these images in lectures, articles and tours to help publicize the dilemma. In 1912, Congress established the National Elk Refuge to provide wintering grounds for elk.
audioDescription:
Stephen Leek's Camera Conservation.

This wayside is next to a paved sidewalk above the parking lot at Leeks Marina. The sign looks out a gravelly sloped clearing in a wooded area. About 20 yards away, slightly to the left is a stone fireplace with a broken stone chimney.

The background image on the sign shows a historic photograph of a dozen dead elk, lying on the ground next to the wall of a log cabin. Two other elk stand in the background. Text along the bottom of the sign reads, "Stephen Leek pioneered the first conservation movement in Jackson Hole. Starting out as a fishing and hunting guide, he later became a passionate campaigner for the Jackson elk herd. Leek's glass plate photographs of starving and dead elk nationally publicized the tragic effects of winter habitat loss. In 1912, Congress approved the creation of the National Elk Refuge.

"The establishment of the National Elk Refuge marked an important change in attitudes about land use here. Once opposed, homesteaders began supporting the government purchase of land for conservation."

In the lower left hand corner is a smaller photo of a man with a white mustache, wearing a broad brimmed hat. He stands in a snowy landscape holding a pan of food, surrounded by elk.

In the upper right corner is a small photograph of a man inside a log building. He is sitting in a rocking chair next to the fireplace you see before you. The caption reads, "Homesteader, businessman and conservationist Stephen Leek built a lodge here in 1927. All that remains of the lodge is this chimney."

title: String Lake Launch
listingDescription: Location: The String Lake Canoe launch is the middle of three parking lots in the String Lake area. Access String Lake from the Jenny Lake Scenic Drive. The farthest parking lot provides access to the String Lake picnic area and the Leigh Lake Trailhead. Notes: This area is very congested during summer especially from late morning through afternoon. Please obey all regulations. There is no boat ramp at this location. Visitors must carry their watercraft to the lake. No moto

images.altText: Visitors picnicking on lake shore and carrying boat to water.
images.caption: Visitors at String Lake Launch

bodyText:
Location: The String Lake Canoe launch is the middle of three parking lots in the String Lake area. Access String Lake from the Jenny Lake Scenic Drive. The farthest parking lot provides access to the String Lake picnic area and the Leigh Lake Trailhead.

Notes: This area is very congested during summer especially from late morning through afternoon. Please obey all regulations. There is no boat ramp at this location. Visitors must carry their watercraft to the lake. No motors are allowed on String Lake. Water, restrooms, picnic area and additional parking is available at the String Lake picnic area.

Regulations

All boats including paddleboards launched in Grand Teton National Park must have a park permit. Purchase permits at the permits desk in the Craig Thomas Discovery & Visitor Center in Moose or the Colter Bay permits office. More information on park boat regulations.

Boat inspections required for all boats entering Wyoming between March 1 and November 30 for Aquatic Invasive Species (AIS). AIS inspection stations near Moose and Moran. Boat owners must buy a decal to support this program. More information on state boat regulations .

Name Origin

The shallow lake between Leigh and Jenny lakes was named Beaver Dick Lake in 1931 after Richard "Beaver Dick" Leigh who guided the 1872 Hayden Survey. The name changed back to String Lake sometime later in the 1930s.
audioDescription: The concrete path from the parking lot leads to the dirt and gravel shore of the lake. The water at the edge is shallow, providing easy access for canoe and kayak launches. At the far side of the lake the bases of Mount St John and Rockchuck Peak rise steeply with the rocky summits towering above. To your right is an accessible trail along the shore of the lake.

title: String Lake Picnic Area
listingDescription: String Lake picnic area is one of the largest and most popular in the park! Tables are scattered along the lakeshore under a stand of lodgepole pines. The lake is the warmest in the park and is a popular place to swim, kayak, canoe or play on a standup paddleboard. Families often spend the afternoon picnicking and enjoying the lake. In addition to water activities, the picnic area is also located between the String and Leigh lake trailheads. Offering access to classic hikes i

images.altText: Visitors at String Lake with chairs set up on the shore looking north toward Mount Moran.
images.caption: Sitting on the edge of String Lake

bodyText:
String Lake picnic area is one of the largest and most popular in the park! Tables are scattered along the lakeshore under a stand of lodgepole pines. The lake is the warmest in the park and is a popular place to swim, kayak, canoe or play on a standup paddleboard. Families often spend the afternoon picnicking and enjoying the lake. In addition to water activities, the picnic area is also located between the String and Leigh lake trailheads. Offering access to classic hikes in the Teton Range.

Name Origin

The shallow lake between Leigh and Jenny lakes was named Beaver Dick Lake in 1931 after Richard "Beaver Dick" Leigh who guided the 1872 Hayden Survey. The name changed back to String Lake sometime later in the 1930s.

title: String Lake Trailhead
listingDescription: Location: Access the String Lake Trailhead from the Jenny Lake scenic loop drive. Turn west at North Jenny Lake Junction, bend north where the road splits and choose from a series of parking lots. The first parking lot is the String Lake Trailhead. The second lot serves as a canoe launch for String Lake. The third lot provides access to the Leigh Lake Trailhead and the String Lake Picnic Area. Notes: This area is popular for picnicking and water sports. Parking is often con

images.altText: Hikers on bridge across the outlet of String Lake just past trailhead with view of the Cathedral Group and Mount St. John
images.caption: Hikers on String Lake Bridge

bodyText:
Location: Access the String Lake Trailhead from the Jenny Lake scenic loop drive. Turn west at North Jenny Lake Junction, bend north where the road splits and choose from a series of parking lots. The first parking lot is the String Lake Trailhead. The second lot serves as a canoe launch for String Lake. The third lot provides access to the Leigh Lake Trailhead and the String Lake Picnic Area.

Notes: This area is popular for picnicking and water sports. Parking is often congested mid-day especially on weekends. Restrooms and water are located at the Leigh Lake trailhead. Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray. Backcountry camping requires a permit-pick one up at a backcountry permits office.

Destinations

Hikers may choose from a wide variety of options. Some may opt for the relatively level trail that begins along the east shore of String Lake and extends north to Leigh, Bearpaw and Trapper lakes. Others may enjoy a loop around String Lake with views of the Jackson Hole valley. For those looking for a longer hike, venture up Cascade or Paintbrush canyons to reach the alpine lakes such as Lake Solitude and Holly Lake.

String Lake Loop
3.7 miles RT, 2 hours, 325 ft total climbing, Easy.
Trail circles the lake through a burned area below Rockchuck Peak and Mount St. John.

Paintbrush-Cascade Loop
19.0 miles RT, 13 hours, 4350 ft total climbing, Very Strenuous.
Spectacular hike loops two canyons via Paintbrush Divide. An ice axe may be necessary through July.

Name Origin

The shallow lake between Leigh and Jenny lakes was named Beaver Dick Lake in 1931 after Richard "Beaver Dick" Leigh who guided the 1872 Hayden Survey. The name changed back to String Lake sometime later in the 1930s.
audioDescription: This is a three-panel sign covered by a small roof. To your left, a wide dirt path leads back to the parking area. To your right, the trail slopes down gently through open meadows past a wayside sign. Further on the trail turns right and crosses a wooden bridge over the stream between String Lake and Jenny Lake.The center panel on the sign shows a map of the area around Jenny Lake sitting at the mouth of Cascade Canyon between Teewinot Mountain and Mount St. John. North is behind you and to your right. You are currently located toward the bottom of the map between String Lake and Jenny Lake. Dotted lines show the trails that can be accessed from this location. The panel reads, "Explore Your Park. String Lake, a narrow, mile-long lake, connects Leigh and Jenny lakes. Enjoy a short level trail on the east side of the lake, or climb into Paintbrush Canyon for a more strenuous trip."A fire burned the area between Jenny and String lakes in 1999. Walk southwest across the String Lake bridge toward Jenny Lake to see how fire has rejuvenated this landscape."DID YOU REMEMBER?- Sunscreen: The sun burns quickly at this elevation.- Clothing Layers: Weather can change suddenly.- Plenty of Food & Water: Avoid the dangers of dehydration and fatigue.- Bug Spray: Don't let mosquitoes ruin your trip.- Map & Watch: Avoid spending an unplanned night in the backcountry with careful planning and routefinding.- Bear Spray: Both grizzly and black bears thrive in Grand Teton National Park."RECOMMENDED ROUTES- Jenny Lake - Head southwest then cross the bridge over String Lake and continue southwest to meet the shore of Jenny Lake. Walk through an old burn to see how plants and animals now thrive in this open forest. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 1.3 miles; DURATION: 1 hour; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 150 feet; DIFFICULTY: easy.- String Lake Loop - Hike southwest to cross the String Lake bridge, joining the trail that travels along the base of Rockchuck Peak. Return east to String Lake. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 3.7 miles; DURATION: 2 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 550 feet; DIFFICULTY: easy to moderate.- Holly Lake - Follow the Paintbrush Canyon trail through wildflower meadows to an alpine lake. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 13 miles; DURATION: 8 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 2,900 feet; DIFFICULTY: strenuous.- Paintbrush-Cascade Loop - Spectacular hike links Paintbrush and Cascade canyons via Paintbrush Divide passing Lake Solitude. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 19 miles; DURATION: 12 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 4,900 feet; DIFFICULTY: very strenuous."* Duration and degree of difficulty will vary individually. For more trip suggestions ask at a visitor center."Stock Users - Inquire at a visitor center, ranger station or entrance station for regulations and trails open to stock.Emergencies - The nearest telephone is located at the Jenny Lake Lodge, about 1/2 mile southeast of here."Did You Know? String Lake was briefly known as Beaver Dick Lake in the1930s. Richard "Beaver Dick" Leigh, a British expatriate, guided the Hayden Expedition of 1872 through the Teton area. String Lake has been a popular swimming hole since the early 1900s. Early homesteaders and guests at nearby dude ranches came here to cool off and enjoy the scenery."The left hand panel has a photograph of a climber on the side of a rock face with a jagged peak visible in the background. Text reads, "Protect the Backcountry. "HIKING, CAMPING & STOCK USE- All overnight stays require a backcountry camping permit. Permits are available year-round at the visitor center in Moose, and during the summer at Jenny Lake Ranger Station and Colter Bay Visitor Center.- Pack out all trash. Keep the park litter-free for all to enjoy.- Stay on established trails. Shortcutting switchbacks damages plants and causes erosion.- Backcountry campfires are allowed ONLY at designated lakeshore sites and must be confined to metal grates or with a permit below the Jackson Lake high water line.- Backpackers must use park-approved bear-resistant canisters or food storage lockers when camping below 10,000 feet.- Saddle and pack animals must stay on authorized trails and may not graze in the park. Find out more at a visitor center."CLIMBING & MOUNTAINEERING- Registration is not required for technical climbing or mountaineering; however, a permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry.- Tell a friend or family member your plans and when you expect to return.- During summer visit the Jenny Lake Ranger Station for details on climbing routes and current conditions.- Follow low impact climbing ethics. Leave the rock in its natural condition. Avoid placing permanent protection. Motorized drills are prohibited.- RESOURCE PROTECTION & FIREARMS- Leave the park as you found it for others to enjoy. Picking wildflowers or collecting any object is prohibited.- Hikers must be prepared for wildlife encounters. Do not approach or harass animals. Stay at least 300 feet from large mammals such as moose, bison, elk or bears for your safety

title: T.A. Moulton Barn
listingDescription:
The T.A. Moulton barn is an iconic structure in Jackson Hole. The sunrise view with the barn in the foreground and the Teton Range as the backdrop is one of the most photographed locales in the valley.

Thomas Alva (T.A.) Moulton and his brother John homesteaded on Mormon Row in 1908. T.A. built a frame house in 1915 and dry farmed grain until the state built irrigation ditches to their property in the late 1920s. In 1930, the Snake River Land Company met with the Mormon Row settlers and many sold their property with most securing lifetime leases. By the 1950s, few remained.

images.altText: Classic view of TA Moulton barn with a stand of cottonwood trees to the right and the Teton Range in the background.
images.caption: TA Moulton Barn

bodyText:
The T.A. Moulton barn is an iconic structure in Jackson Hole. The sunrise view with the barn in the foreground and the Teton Range as the backdrop is one of the most photographed locales in the valley.

Thomas Alva (T.A.) Moulton and his brother John homesteaded on Mormon Row in 1908. T.A. built a frame house in 1915 and dry farmed grain until the state built irrigation ditches to their property in the late 1920s. In 1930, the Snake River Land Company met with the Mormon Row settlers and many sold their property with most securing lifetime leases. By the 1950s, few remained.
audioDescription: This barn sits in the middle of a field back from the road. The central part has a high peaked roof covered with worn metal roofing. The front peak extends out to form a triangle-shaped projection. On either side of the main structure are wings covered with lower sloped roofs. The barn is made of logs, vertical on the main part, horizontal on the two side-wings. Each of the wings has a single door next to the outside walls. In clear weather, the jagged peaks of the central Tetons are visible in the background.

title: Taggart Lake Trailhead
listingDescription:
Location: Access the Taggart Lake trailhead from the Teton Park Road three and a half miles northwest from Moose Junction.

Notes: Visitor services include a modest-sized parking lot, a vault toilet, map brochure box, bike rack and a trailhead sign. Remember to bring water with you. Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray. Backcountry camping requires a permit-pick one up at a backcountry permits office.

images.altText: Looking past the Taggart Lake Trailhead along a dirt trail through a sagebrush meadow and the Grand Teton in the distance.
images.caption: Taggart Lake Trailhead

bodyText:
Location: Access the Taggart Lake trailhead from the Teton Park Road three and a half miles northwest from Moose Junction.

Notes: Visitor services include a modest-sized parking lot, a vault toilet, map brochure box, bike rack and a trailhead sign. Remember to bring water with you. Bears may be active any place and at any time-travel in groups, make noise and carry bear spray. Backcountry camping requires a permit-pick one up at a backcountry permits office.

Destinations

The Taggart Lake area offers several loop trail options. Head west toward the mountains, climb a glacial moraine mantled in aspen and lodgepole pines and descend to Taggart Lake. This glacial lake lies at the mouth of Avalanche Canyon.

From Taggart Lake, you may continue north to reach Bradley Lake, another glacial lake at the mouth of Garnet Canyon. To complete the loop, continue south along the Valley Trail. If you venture beyond Bradley Lake you can intersect the Lupine Meadows trail.

Taggart Lake
3.0 miles RT, 2 hours, 350 ft total climbing, Easy.
Out-and-back trail traverses sagebrush flats and forests to a lake with views of the Grand Teton.

Taggart Lake-Beaver Creek Loop
3.9 miles RT, 2 hours, 500 ft total climbing, Moderate.
Hike this trail to the lake, climb the glacial moraine and return along Beaver Creek.

Taggart Lake-Bradley Lake
5.9 miles RT, 3 hours, 800 ft total climbing, Moderate.
Loop hike visits two lakes dammed by glacial moraines.

Name Origin

Named for W. Rush Taggart, the assistant geologist with the 1872 Hayden Expedition. Taggart first came to Jackson Hole in 1860 with Captain W.F. Raynolds and the army engineers.
audioDescription: This three-panel sign at the edge of the parking area is covered by a small roof. Beyond the sign a wide, flat dirt and gravel path leads through the meadow towards low, tree-covered hills with the Teton range rising steeply behind. On the other side of the path from the sign is a single, unisex vault toilet.The center panel on the sign shows a map of the range from Mount Owen on the right to Buck Mountain on the left. In the middle Taggart Lake lies at the end of Avalanche Canyon between Mount Wister on the left and South Teton on the right. Your current location at Taggart Lake Trailhead is at the bottom center of the map at the side of Teton Park Road. Dotted lines show the trails that can be accessed from this location. The panel reads, "Explore Your Park. This popular trailhead leads to two glacially carved lakes. Take a short walk to Taggart Lake, and if you have time, visit Bradley Lake for excellent views. A fire burned this area in 1985. As you hike look for burned trees and notice how the forest has regenerated. This successional forest supports a variety of animals and plants."DID YOU REMEMBER?- Sunscreen: The sun burns quickly at this elevation.- Clothing Layers: Weather can change suddenly.- Plenty of Food & Water: Avoid the dangers of dehydration and fatigue.- Bug Spray: Don't let mosquitoes ruin your trip.- Map & Watch: Avoid spending an unplanned night in the backcountry with careful planning and routefinding.- Bear Spray: Both grizzly and black bears thrive in Grand Teton National Park."RECOMMENDED ROUTES- Taggart Lake - Hike to the lake and back on the same trail. Walk through an old burn to see how plants and animals now thrive in this open forest. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 3 miles; DURATION: 2 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 400 feet; DIFFICULTY: easy.- Taggart Lake Loop - Hike to Taggart Lake and then continue south on the loop over a glacial moraine through forest and sagebrush meadow, returning along Beaver Creek. Watch for black bears. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 3.9 miles; DURATION: 2 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 500 feet; DIFFICULTY: easy to moderate.- Taggart Lake - Bradley Lake - Hike to Bradley Lake then follow the trail along the eastern shore of Taggart Lake. Follow the Taggart loop trail south and east along Beaver Creek to the trailhead. MILEAGE ROUNDTRIP: 5.9 miles; DURATION: 3 hours; TOTAL ELEVATION CHANGE: 900 feet; DIFFICULTY: moderate."* Duration and degree of difficulty will vary individually. For more trip suggestions ask at a visitor center."Stock Users - Inquire at a visitor center, ranger station or entrance station for regulations and trails open to stock."Emergencies - The nearest telephone is located at the Craig Thomas Discovery and Visitor Center in Moose, about 3 miles southeast of here."Did You Know? Glaciers flowing out of Avalanche Canyon carved Taggart Lake ending 15,000 years ago. This lake bears the name of W. Rush Taggart who was a geology assistant for the 1872 Hayden Expedition. In 1911, homesteader James Manges built a distinctive cabin located near this trail, likely the first two-story structure built in this area."The left hand panel has a photograph of a climber on the side of a rock face with a jagged peak visible in the background. Text reads, "Protect the Backcountry. "HIKING, CAMPING & STOCK USE- All overnight stays require a backcountry camping permit. Permits are available year-round at the visitor center in Moose, and during the summer at Jenny Lake Ranger Station and Colter Bay Visitor Center.- Pack out all trash. Keep the park litter-free for all to enjoy.- Stay on established trails. Shortcutting switchbacks damages plants and causes erosion.- Backcountry campfires are allowed ONLY at designated lakeshore sites and must be confined to metal grates or with a permit below the Jackson Lake high water line.- Backpackers must use park-approved bear-resistant canisters or food storage lockers when camping below 10,000 feet.- Saddle and pack animals must stay on authorized trails and may not graze in the park. Find out more at a visitor center."CLIMBING & MOUNTAINEERING- Registration is not required for technical climbing or mountaineering; however, a permit is required for all overnight stays in the backcountry.- Tell a friend or family member your plans and when you expect to return.- During summer visit the Jenny Lake Ranger Station for details on climbing routes and current conditions.- Follow low impact climbing ethics. Leave the rock in its natural condition. Avoid placing permanent protection. Motorized drills are prohibited.- RESOURCE PROTECTION & FIREARMS- Leave the park as you found it for others to enjoy. Picking wildflowers or collecting any object is prohibited.- Hikers must be prepared for wildlife encounters. Do not approach or harass animals. Stay at least 300 feet from large mammals such as moose, bison, elk or bears for your safety and theirs.- Wildlife often bite the hand that feeds them-do not feed any animal, including squirrels, chipmu

title: Taggart Pathway Access
listingDescription:
The Taggart Lake Trailhead provides a convenient access to the multi-use pathway for those looking for a short outing. With views of the Grand Teton to the west and Cottonwood Creek to the east, the scenery is spectacular. A four-mile trek north will take you to South Jenny Lake, or a three-mile trek south will take you to Moose. The parking lot provides visitors with access to hiking and the pathway and may become congested. ADA compliant.

Facilities include a vault toilet and bike rack, but no water.

images.altText: Bicyclist riding past Taggart Lake Pathway signs on multi-use pathway.
images.caption: Bicyclist on Multi-use Pathway at Taggart Lake Trailhead

bodyText:
The Taggart Lake Trailhead provides a convenient access to the multi-use pathway for those looking for a short outing. With views of the Grand Teton to the west and Cottonwood Creek to the east, the scenery is spectacular. A four-mile trek north will take you to South Jenny Lake, or a three-mile trek south will take you to Moose. The parking lot provides visitors with access to hiking and the pathway and may become congested. ADA compliant.

Facilities include a vault toilet and bike rack, but no water.

Regulations

Only use non-motorized forms of transportation on the multi-use pathway. Persons with physical disabilities may use battery-operated transportation. Do not access the pathway from dusk to dawn for your safety and wildlife's safety. Please do not walk your dog on the pathway. Guide dogs-used for the sole purpose of aiding a person with a physical disability-may travel on the pathway.

Name Origin

Named for W. Rush Taggart, the assistant geologist with the 1872 Hayden Expedition. Taggart first came to Jackson Hole in 1860 with Captain W.F. Raynolds and the army engineers.
audioDescription:
The multi-use Pathway runs alongside the parking area here at the Taggart Lake Trailhead.
There is a large, three-panel sign located near the pathway providing information on safety, park regulations and a map.
The center panel shows a map of the pathway between Moose Junction in the south and the southern end of Jenny Lake in the north. The pathway runs alongside the Teton Park Road for most of this stretch, only diverging slightly to the west as it approaches Jenny Lake Visitor Center.

The title on the right hand panel reads, "No Pets on Pathway" and shows a picture of a dog with the universal not-allowed symbol of a red circle with a line across it. The text reads, "PETS ARE NOT PERMITTED on the park pathway. Guide dogs-used for the sole purpose of aiding a person with physical disability-may travel on the pathway. The pathway travels through sensitive wildlife areas.

"Why Are Pets Not Allowed? For the wildlife and for your safety.
o Wildlife such as bears, wolves or coyotes may be drawn to pets and their owners.
o A surprise encounter with wildlife may result in death or injury to pets, wildlife or visitors.
o Pets may escape and quickly become prey.
o Dogs cause the same stress responses in prey species (such as elk and pronghorn) as predators do.
o Transmittable diseases, such as parvovirus, from infected feces may live in the soil for months, passing on to wildlife.

"WHERE CAN PETS GO?
"OUTSIDE THE PARK
o Jackson Hole Community Pathways except on the National Elk Refuge.
o Bridger-Teton National Forest trails-Shadow Mountain, Gros Ventre River, Snow King, Cache Creek, Phillips Canyon and Teton Pass.
o Snake River dike, at the intersection of highways WY 22 & 390 in Wilson.

"INSIDE THE PARK
"In general, leashed pets may go anywhere a car may go-roads and road shoulders, campgrounds, picnic areas, and parking lots. Pets must be in control and restrained on a leash no longer than six feet in length."

At the bottom of the panel are photographs of a bull moose and a male sage grouse, its large white chest puffed up. The text reads, "SAGEBRUSH COMMUNITY. The drought-tolerant plants of the sagebrush community thrive despite porous, cobbly soils and intense sunlight. These flowering plants form one of the most colorful and diverse communities in the park. Sagebrush provides a mosaic of food and shelter for a variety of animals."

The panel on the left is titled "Protect Your Park." In a light green color block at the top left there is a photograph of two people on bicycles on the path with Grand Teton in the background. Text reads, "How to Ride. Only NON-MOTORIZED METHODS of transportation are permitted on the multi-use pathway. Persons with physical disabilities may use electric and battery-operated transportation. Horses are not permitted on the pathway, except on the Snake River bridge in Moose.
o Travel single file in the right-side lane; share the pathway.
o Notify other recreators before you pass. Be aware of others passing you.
o The use of portable audio devices is strongly discouraged.
o Obey all traffic signs. Yield to all vehicles.
o Yield to slower recreators.
o Wear a helmet.
o Stay on paved pathway; no shortcutting through vegetation.
Absolutely no pets allowed. Respect the rights of all users."

In the center of the panel is a photograph of a small herd of pronghorn . The caption reads, "Help wildlife thrive. NEVER FEED, APPROACH OR HARASS WILDLIFE-especially large mammals. Stay at least 100 yards away from bears and wolves, and 25 yards from other animals. Be prepared for wildlife interactions; be prepared to stop."

At the bottom of the panel is a photograph of two bears standing in snow at the edge of a pond, drinking. The caption reads, "Be Bear Aware. Grizzly and black bears may become aggressive when surprised or in defense of young. Stay alert and make bears aware of your presence. Follow food storage regulations: never leave your backpack, pannier or any item with food unattended. Carry and know how to use bear spray."

There are two smaller photograph in a border down the right side of the panel. The first one shows an elk with a full set of antlers. The caption reads, "When to Ride. The multi-use pathway is CLOSED from dusk to dawn for wildlife and public safety."

The bottom photo shows a single tree backlit by a sun low in the sky. The caption reads, "Leave No Trace. The park PROHIBITS PICKING, COLLECTING OR DESTROYING park resources.
